questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: The following image shows a multi-parameter monitor with normal pulse waveforms. Which of the following phenomenons is responsible for the finding marked in yellow arrows in the waveforms?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with yellow coloured arrows in the pulse waveforms is indicative of the dicrotic notch. Dicrotic notch is caused by the closing of the aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shuts.

questions.text: Which of the following mediators of inflammation is an example of a C-X3-C chemokine?
questions.solution:
Fractalkine is an example of a C-X3-C chemokine.

CX3C chemokines contain three amino acids between the two cysteines. The only known member of this class is fractalkine. This chemokine exists in two forms which acts as a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital with dehydration and generalised weakness. He was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 2 years ago. Investigations revealed metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. Urine analysis showed a pH of 5.1, glycosuria, and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with hypokalemia and urine pH of 5.1, type 2 renal tubular acidosis (adult Fanconi’s syndrome) is the likely diagnosis. It is commonly associated with multiple myeloma.

Normally, light chains are filtered, reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, and catabolized. In multiple myeloma, there is an increased amount of light chains and the tubular cells are overloaded. 

This leads to proximal tubular damage either directly from light chain toxic effects or indirectly from the release of intracellular lysosomal enzymes.

Clinical features of renal tubular acidosis type 2:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Urine pH <5.3
  • Proteinuria (only light chains)
  • Glycosuria
  • Aminoaciduria

Alport's syndrome is characterised by hematuria, hearing loss and eye abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

questions.text: Which among the following would you use for the measurement of intraocular pressure in a patient with a scarred cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.

It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.

Types of tonometry:

  • Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer  
  • Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types -
    • Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
    • Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.
  • Self-measurement: Rebound
  • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
  • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg

Recent tonometers:

  • Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP measurement.
  • Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact

Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow.

The image given below shows fluorescein-stained semicircular mires.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old obese woman has recently been diagnosed with NASH. She is non-diabetic and non-hypertensive, and she has never consumed alcohol. On evaluation, there is no evidence of cirrhosis and cardiovascular diseases. Which of the following can be considered the first line of treatment for this lady?

NASH: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
questions.solution:
Vitamin E can be considered the first line of treatment in this patient with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Vitamin E is well tolerated and has been shown to modestly improve aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. However, vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic, noncirrhotic NASH patients who are at low risk for cardiovascular disease or prostate cancer. 

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

NASH is characterized by hepatic steatosis, which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation.

Most patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work.

Some patients with NASH may present with right upper quadrant pain owing to the stretching of the liver capsule as a result of hepatomegaly or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance; some may present with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis.

Currently, biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia.

Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box which is used to mask non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman diagnosed with uterine prolapse, now presented with dyspareunia and fecal incontinence. After manually reducing the prolapse, a peristaltic bulge is seen in the posterior vaginal wall. What is the preferred method of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an enterocele associated with fecal incontinence. It is preferably repaired using an abdominal approach like Moschcowitz repair.

An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features:

  • Fecal incontinence
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Constipation/diarrhea
  • Mass descending PV
  • Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort
  • A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:
    • Upper 1/3rd - enterocele
    • Lower 2/3rd - rectocele
  • Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge 

Enterocele repair is done via the following methods:

  • Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated. 
  • Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes:
    • Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.
    • Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally. 

Option B: Purandare's sling operation is abdominal wall cervicopexy for uterine prolapse. It is done for young nulliparous women.

Option D: Le Fort's repair is done in elderly patients with uterine prolapse, who are unfit for surgery.

Note: Enteroceles may be present along with uterine prolapse. Failure to identify and repair it during vaginal hysterectomy can lead to vault prolapse.

Related Pearl: Management of Vaginal prolapse

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has presented to the OPD with a complaint of erectile dysfunction not responding to oral medication. The issue is determined to be of vascular origin. Which prostaglandin preparation can be given as a local injection to treat this?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil (PGE1) is given as an intracavernosal injection or urethral suppository for erectile dysfunction.

It is considered as a second-line therapy. Its use has been largely replaced by phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors like sildenafil and tadalafil which are the drugs of choice.

questions.text:
Which of the following would be considered significant hematuria?

hpf - high power field
questions.solution:
The criteria for significant hematuria is RBC >100 in a single urinalysis.

Hematuria is considered significant (or persistent) when:

  • RBC >3/hpf on >3 occasions
  • RBC >100 in single urinalysis
  • Gross hematuria

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding a Wolfe graft except:
questions.solution:
Wolfes graft is a type of full-thickness graft. The best cosmetic appearance is seen with a full-thickness graft.

Full-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and the complete layer of the dermis. They are used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin is required.

Full-thickness grafts are associated with,

  • The greatest amount of primary contraction
  • The least amount of secondary contraction
  • The highest durability
  • The best cosmetic appearance

As a result, they are frequently used in reconstructing superficial wounds on the face and the hands.

  Full-thickness skin graft (Wolfe) Split thickness skin graft (Thiersche)
Structure Epidermis + complete dermis ± fat Epidermis + part of dermis
Donor site location Post auricular, supra/infra-clavicular. 
Never axillary		 Thigh > buttocks
Donor site wound Must be sutured Requires only dressing and can be reused
Recipient site Must be well vascularised. Small area May be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)
Graft features
Durability High Low
Contracture Primary > secondary High secondary contracture
Uptake Require more care to ensure uptake High-reliability
Cosmetic result Good Poor (abnormal pigmentation)

questions.text: Which of the following condition commonly has an appearance of watered silk on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
On fundus examination, the Hypermetropic eye has a bright reflex suggesting the appearance of watered silk.

Signs of hypermetropia include the following:

  • Size of the eyeball: small.
  • The cornea may be slightly smaller.
  • Short anteroposterior length of the eyeball.
  • Fundus picture:
    • Pseudopapillitis - characterized by a small optic disc, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins and without disc edema
    • Watered silk appearance - The retina, as a whole, may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections.

The convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a violent attack. The patient has injuries over her forearm and elbow. On examination, she has injuries over her breasts and inner thighs. Pelvic examination reveals lacerations in the vaginal mucosa. On enquiring about the injuries, the patient is unable to remember the violent incident. Which of the following defense mechanism best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and examination are suggestive of rape, and the patient is repressing the memory of the incident as a means of coping with the anxiety.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: You prescribe an antibiotic course for a patient following cesarean section. What advice would you give regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Avoid breastfeeding during the antibiotic course
Medications to be taken 3-4 hours before next feeding

questions.solution:
If the lactating mother needs to take medications that are deemed safe, the optimal dosing time should be 30-60 minutes after nursing and at least 3-4 hours before the next feeding.

A minimum interval of 3-4 hours allows time for partial clearance of the drug. This ensures the infants are not exposed to the peak maternal plasma concentration that may translate to higher levels secreted into milk. 

Other options: 

Option A: Most drugs administered are detected in breast milk, but most of them are excreted in very small quantities that do not cause any effect in the infants. 

Option B: Breastfeeding should not be avoided altogether for all medications. Intake of cytotoxic agents and immunomodulatory agents are contraindications for breastfeeding. 

Option D: The timing of medication should preferably be at an interval where the infants are not exposed to higher maternal plasma concentrations.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

questions.text: How efficacious is the hypochlorous acid, when compared to the hypochlorite ions in terms of its disinfecting action?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: During a field trip, an 11-year-old boy consumes a wild mushroom which was later identified to be a death cap mushroom.  Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by the toxin from this mushroom?
questions.solution:
The mushroom death cap (also known as Amanita phalloides) produces the toxin, α-amanitin which inhibits RNA polymerase.

In eukaryotes, α-Amanitin forms a tight complex with the polymerase, thereby inhibiting mRNA synthesis and, ultimately, protein synthesis.

Note: Rifampicin inhibits the prokaryotic DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Orphan drugs are drugs that are not used anymore.
  2. Orphan drugs are drugs for rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies.
  3. Orphan drugs act on orphan receptors.
  4. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.
  5. Orphan receptors are receptors that do not serve any purpose.
questions.solution:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.

There are two types of drug development. They are:

  • Traditional drug development: Initial drug discovery is followed by the characterization of the receptors the drugs are used to act on.
  • Contemporary drug development: Due to advances in molecular biology and genome sequencing, receptors are identified initially. These receptors do not have an endogenous mediator or ligand and are thus known as orphan receptors. However, they are potential targets for the development of new drugs, which can later be identified using chemical screening. 

Orphan drugs are drugs used for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases. Special incentives are given by the government to pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs. Examples of orphan drugs are:

  • Liposomal amphotericin B
  • Digoxin antibody (Digibind)
  • Fomepizole

questions.text: Which of the following is the false statement regarding Laennec cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Laennec cirrhosis is the classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in end-stage alcoholic liver disease.

Long-term alcohol use results in perisinusoidal scarring, leading to diffuse nodularity of the liver surface.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstinence from the further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

questions.text: A child was brought to you with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain. USG revealed left-sided hydronephrosis. On the third follow-up day, a decrease in abdominal pain was noted after he passed a large amount of urine. Repeat USG showed a significant decrease in the size of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amount of urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis.

It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominal pain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein.

In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along with renal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, the patient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This is termed Dietl's crisis.

In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.

questions.text: The cluster differentiation of selectins is _________
questions.solution:
The cluster differentiation of selectins is CD62.

There are three types of selectins:

  • L-selectin on leukocytes - CD62L
  • E-selectin on endothelium - CD62E
  • P-selectin in platelets - CD62P

The two major families of molecules involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration are the selectins and integrins. The initial rolling interactions are mediated by a family of proteins called selectins. These are low-affinity interactions with a fast off-rate, and they are easily disrupted by the flowing blood.

The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to infection and injury.

Related Pearl: Selectins and Associated Ligands

Molecule

Distribution

Ligand

L- selectin (CD62L)

Neutrophils, monocytes

T cells (naïve and central memory)

B cells (naïve)

Sialyl–Lewis X/PNAd on GlyCAM-1, CD34, MAdCAM-1 Others; expressed on endothelium (HEV)

E- selectin (CD62E)

Endothelium activated by cytokines (TNF, IL-1

P- selectin (CD62P)

Endothelium activated by cytokines (TN, IL-1), histamine, or thrombin

Sialyl–Lewis X on PSGL- 1 and other glycoproteins; expressed on neutrophils, monocytes, T cells (effector, memory)

questions.text: Which stage of syphilitic keratitis has ghost vessels?
questions.solution:
The 'ghost vessels' are seen in the stage of regression or healing of syphilitic keratitis.

The syphilitic keratitis is characterized by a moderate degree of superficial vascularization. Once the cornea starts healing, the cloudiness disappears and the vessels become obliterated. Even though they stop carrying blood they remain permanently as fine opaque lines known as ‘ghost vessels’. The characteristic radial course of the vessels indicates the previous occurrence of the disease.

Stages of interstital keratitis in congenital syphilis:

  • Initial progressive: Ground-glass appearance
  • Florid stage: Salmon patch appearance
  • Stage of regression: Ghost vessels

questions.text: A 54-year-old man had  presented to the clinic with a history of chronic cough. His chest X-ray showed a mass in the left lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass was done and findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition include Cave's disease and Ohio disease.

The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.

Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages.

On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidia are seen. Diagnosis is mainly by urinary or blood antigens. 

It is treated using azole antifungals.

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of bloody sputum. There was a history of tonsillectomy 1 week back. On examination, the bleeding was from the tonsillar bed. What is the type of hemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a secondary hemorrhage. It results due to sepsis and premature membranes separation.

Note:

  • Primary hemorrhage - Occurs at the time of operation.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage - Occurs within a period of 24 hours.
  • Secondary hemorrhage - Usually seen between the fifth to tenth post-operative days

questions.text: Regarding the two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis which of the following is true?

choices.text: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.solution:
The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis:

  • Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types:
    • The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and
    • The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum
  • The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to the follicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supported aromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedione because of the lack of the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is absence seizures. Hyperventilation provokes it.

The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begin and end suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background.

An absence seizure is characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. The seizures can occur hundreds of times per day, but the child may be unaware of or unable to convey their existence.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows splenic laceration. 

Splenic lacerations are linear low attenuation parenchymal defects and are almost always associated with haemoperitoneum.

The spleen is the visceral organ most commonly injured in blunt trauma abdomen. Severely ill patients may present with hypovolemic shock manifesting as tachycardia, hypotension, and pallor. A splenic rupture may not always be clinically apparent and spontaneous splenic rupture or pathological rupture can occur after minor trauma or insignificant events.

Investigation of choice in blunt trauma abdomen is CECT.

Splenic injury are currently classified into five grades based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) splenic injury scale (revised in 2018).

Management of splenic trauma:

  • Nonoperative management is preferred for stable grade I, II, or III splenic injuries.
  • Splenectomy is done for grade IV and V injuries.

CT showing splenic laceration and hematoma:

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following excludes live birth?

choices.text: Presence of milk in the stomach

questions.solution:
Signs of maceration clearly excludes live birth and indicates early intrauterine death. However, putrefaction should not be interpreted as maceration.

Confirmatory signs of live birth are :

  • Presence of milk in the stomach
  • Absence of meconium in the large bowel, the exception being breech delivery.
  • Exfoliation of skin
  • Closure of fetal channels
  • Changes in the umbilical cord

Live birth can be excluded if :

  • Signs of maceration are present
  • Signs of immaturity are present. If the child has not attained the viable age (7 months), it could not have been born alive.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and nausea. His ultrasound abdomen revealed grade 2 fatty liver. Which among the following findings is unlikely to be seen in his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. It is usually characterized by an AST: ALT > 2. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate  that is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio.

Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the deficiency of coagulation factors and, usually, does not respond to the administration of parenteral vitamin K. Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Elevated ALP levels are seen due to enzymatic induction by alcohol and mild cholestasis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve.

CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

The tram-track sign is useful in the differentiation between optic nerve meningioma and optic nerve gliomas.

CT may be also useful in detecting calcification within the meningioma which is specific to optic nerve meningioma and not seen in optic nerve glioma.

questions.text: The only mitochondrial step in pyrimidine synthesis is catalyzed by the enzyme ________
questions.solution:
The only mitochondrial step in pyrimidine synthesis is catalyzed by the enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase.

Pyrimidine synthesis primarily happens in the liver in both cytoplasm and mitochondria. The conversion of dihydroorotic acid to orotic acid catalyzed by the enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase is the only step that occurs in mitochondria. The rest of the reaction occurs in the cytoplasm.

CAD enzymes are multifunctional enzymes present in a single polypeptide chain. It includes:

  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-2
  • Aspartate transcarbamoylase
  • Dihydroorotase

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with poor appetite, anger, and sadness. She has had the symptom from the past 14 months ever since her husband died. She also complains of hearing her husband's voice at times. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from persistent bereavement disorder

After the loss of a loved one, there is a grief reaction as in this patient.If the grief reaction extends for more than 12 months in bereaved adults or 6 months in bereaved children, it is called persistent bereavement disorder.  This reaction also occurs with other losses, such as loss of a body part, or, for younger people with a miscarriage or abortion.

Other options:

Option A: Dysthymia is defined as a low mood occurring for at least two years
Option B:The depressive features in this patient are not severe enough for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder
Option C: Normal grief in adults lasts for up to 1 year.

Note: The above information is according to DSM 5.

questions.text: Identify the stage marked by the red arrow________
questions.solution:
The marked stage is the late expanding phase (Stage 3) of the demographic cycle.

The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap.

Note: India is currently in this stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the pharyngeal plexus?
questions.solution:
Stylopharyngeus is not supplied by the pharyngeal plexus. It is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

The pharyngeal plexus is formed by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve with contributions from the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion. It supplies:

  • All muscles of the soft palate 
    • Except tensor veli palatini - supplied by the mandibular nerve
  • All the muscles of the pharynx
    • Except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus presents with skin findings as shown in the image below.  On examination, he complained of pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. On further questioning, the patient revealed that he was started on antidepressants recently. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of diabetes mellitus, antidepressant intake, with pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot(Positive Homan's sign indicating deep vein thrombosis), and the image showing necrolytic migratory rash is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Glucagonoma is a pancreatic islet cell tumor. It is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and depression. It is a state of severe catabolism. Patients present with loss of weight, depletion of protein and fat stores, and vitamin deficiency.  The characteristic skin lesion seen in this condition is the necrolytic migratory erythema which occurs due to severe amino acid deficiency. Providing parental amino acids may help in the disappearance of skin lesions. 

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of more than 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable. 

Other options: 

Option A - Gastrinomas are islet cell tumors that produce large amounts of gastrin. This gastrin does not respond to the normal feedback mechanism and is not suppressed by high luminal pH. Patients with gastrinomas present with abdominal pain and diarrhea. 

Option B - Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad.

Option D - VIPoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the pancreatic D2 islet cells. It is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. It is also referred to as pancreatic cholera. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: The histological section of an intracranial space-occupying lesion resected from a  patient is given below. Which of the following tumors shows this pattern?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells and is seen in oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. It commonly occurs in the fourth and fifth decades. The lesion is found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. 

The tumor is composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around the neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma / Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: The order of depolarization after stimulation of Purkinje fibers is:
questions.solution:
The order of depolarization is from septum → endocardium→ epicardium.

The spread of Cardiac Excitation:

Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on the AV node. A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the ventricles.
Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the midportion of the septum. It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after undergoing an assisted reproductive technique. On routine USG examination, two gestational sacs were found. One in the uterus and another in the ampulla of the left fallopian tube. What is the ideal treatment to remove the extrauterine pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Surgery is the treatment of choice in heterotopic pregnancy.

A normal uterine pregnancy in conjunction with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy is termed a heterotopic pregnancy. Although rare, nowadays, due to an increase in cases of artificial reproduction techniques (ART), the incidence has gone up.

Methotrexate is not to be given as it kills even the normal intrauterine fetus. Although potassium chloride may be injected into the sac of the ectopic, the safer method would be surgery to remove the ectopic.

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. 

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection  
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli.

Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy. 

Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma.

questions.text: According to Brouardel's experiment, what is the minimum tension required for carotid occlusion?
questions.solution:
According to Brouardel's experiment, a minimum of 5kg tension is required for the occlusion of carotid arteries.

The estimation of the force required to occlude the neck structures was done by Brouardel It. 

  • Brouardel’s experiments suggest that a ligature with a tension of 2 kg blocks the jugular return.
  • The force needed to close the trachea was of the order of 15 kg.
  • A ligature with a tension of 30 kg is necessary to occlude the vertebral arteries.

Note: Schwarzacher repeated Brouardel’s experiments in an improved setting, and made a new report that a tension of 3.5 kg was enough to occlude carotid arteries and 16.6 kg to occlude the vertebral arteries.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has been deaf since birth. She now has symptoms suggesting hypothyroidism. Laboratory reports confirmed hypothyroidism and mutated SLC26A4 gene in her. Which of the following steps in the thyroid hormone biosynthesis is expected to be primarily defective in her?

choices.text: Internalisation of colloid into the follicular cells
Secretion of the thyroglobulin into the colloid
Iodide trapping and transport into the follicular cells
Iodide transport across the apical membrane in to the colloid

questions.solution:
The clues from the given clinical scenario such as congenital deafness, the mutation in the SLC26A4 gene, and hypothyroidism are highly suggestive of Pendred syndrome. Hence the transport of iodide across the apical membrane into the colloid is affected in this case.

Pendrin (coded by SLC26A4) is one of the members of the larger family of SLC26 anion exchangers. In the thyroid gland, it is located in the apical membrane of the follicular cell and transports iodide into the colloid in exchange for the chloride ion.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone:

  1. Thyroglobulin synthesis by thyroid follicular cells.
  2. Iodide trapping: Na+-I- symporter (NIS) actively transports I- into the follicular cells. This is inhibited by thiocyanate and perchlorate anions and is stimulated by TSH.
  3. Iodide is transported into the lumen of the follicle by I--Cl- transporter called pendrin.
  4. Oxidation of I- to I2 catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase (TPO).
  5. Organification/Iodination of tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin: Binding of I2  to tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin to form MIT (monoiodotyrosine) and DIT (diiodotyrosine). Catalyzed by TPO.
  6. Coupling reaction mediated by TPO: MIT + DIT → T3, DIT + DIT → T4.
  7. Storage and release: T3 and T4 are stored bound to thyroglobulin. When stimulated, they are cleaved from thyroglobulin and released into the circulation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient suffered a head injury due to a road traffic accident. He couldn't talk and made some sounds. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli and localizes it. What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score for this patient?
questions.solution:
For the given scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 9.

To arrive at this the following clinical points have to be considered:

  • The patient is able to open his eyes to painful stimuli - Eye response = 2
  • The patient is able to make only sounds - Verbal response = 2
  • The patient is able to localize a painful stimulus - Motor response = 5

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Drinking water should not contain any pathogenic organisms or bacteria indicative of fecal contamination. The primary bacterial indicator used to assess this is the coliform group of organisms. This is because they are present abundantly in the human intestine and can be easily detected by culture methods. 

The presumptive coliform test can be done by the multiple tube method or membrane filtration technique. In the multiple tube method, the water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated for 48 hours and examined. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed. McConkey's lactose bile salt broth with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator is used as the media. The number of tubes with production of acid and gas can be assessed to estimate the most probable number of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water. Escherichia coli or thermotolerant coliform bacteria should not be detected in any 100 ml sample. 

In samples of chlorinated water, confirmation of the presumptive test is necessary. This is done by subculturing the positive tubes in two tubes of brilliant green bile broth. It is based on the fact that E.Coli is the only coliform that can produce gas from lactose at 44°C.

Supplementary indicator organisms include fecal streptococci and sulfite-reducing clostridia. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy, who is a known case of asthma, presents with wheezing and rhinitis. Laboratory results show peripheral eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lab findings are suggestive of Churg–Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss Syndrome / Allergic granulomatosis and angiitis is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with:

  • asthma
  • allergic rhinitis
  • asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex
  • lung infiltrates
  • peripheral hypereosinophilia
  • extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

It is a multisystem disease with cutaneous involvement (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract bleeding, and renal disease. Eosinophilic infiltrates may also be seen in the myocardium giving rise to cardiomyopathy.

p- ANCA (MPO-ANCA) is positive in about 50% of cases. Histological features are similar to those observed in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) or microscopic polyangiitis but characteristically accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils.

Eosinophilic vasculitis seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, dizziness, and hyperventilation. His arterial blood gas analysis and serum electrolyte levels revealed metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Which of the following is the possible reason for this condition?
questions.solution:
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap is a feature of renal tubular acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis is a form of hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis which occurs when the renal damage primarily affects tubular function without much effect on glomerular function. The bicarbonate loss leading to acidosis is mirrored by an increase in chloride concentration. Hence the unmeasured anions are unaffected and thus, the anion gap remains within normal limits.

The result is a decrease in H+ excretion which is greater than that can be explained by any change in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). However, if the GFR is significantly depressed eg., renal failure, the retention of fixed acids leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea

Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is emotionally cold, self-absorbed, and pre-occupied with fantasies. He often remains alone, detached from social relationships, and prefers solitary activities. Which cluster of personality disorders does this person belong to?
questions.solution:
An emotionally cold young man preferring loneliness is indicative of a schizoid personality.  Schizoid personality is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

Cluster A: Odd, aloof features. It includes three personality disorders:

  • Paranoid
  • Schizoid
  • Schizotypal

Schizoid personality :

A person who shows a lifelong pattern of being socially distant is said to have a schizoid personality. People with this personality disorder are often introverted, uncomfortable with interactions, and have a bland affect.

Diagnosis: The presence of four or more of the following features which are not attributed to a medical condition indicate schizoid personality:

  • Devoid of close relationships
  • An inclination towards solitary activities
  • Decreased if not any interest in sexual activities
  • Finds pleasure in very few activities
  • Small social circle limited to first degree relatives
  • Indifferent to praise/criticism
  • Blunt affect

Treatment:

  • Psychotherapy
  • Pharmacotherapy is administered in some patients when needed:
    • Low doses of antipsychotics or antidepressants 
    • Benzodiazepines can be used for anxiety

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: During the autopsy of a 90-year-old woman, a normal-looking liver was noted. The following microscopic appearance of hepatocytes was noted. Which of the following cellular mechanisms is likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows brownish lipofuscin granules within the liver cells. It is composed of lipid-containing residues of lysosomal digestion that are formed due to autophagocytosis.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment that is due to free radical injury to the tissue. It is prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

Autophagy is a process by which the cell consumes itself. It involves the sequestration of cellular organelles into cytoplasmic autophagic vacuoles (autophagosomes) that fuse with lysosomes, resulting in the digestion of the enclosed material. It occurs in the following conditions:

  • As a survival mechanism during nutrient deprivation and stress conditions
  • Cancers, inflammatory bowel diseases, neurodegenerative disorders - due to dysregulation

questions.text: A 27- year-old female presents with velvety darkish discoloration of the skin around her neck and arm-pits. She doesn’t have any other symptoms. Which of the following is the most commonly associated condition with the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Velvety darkish discoloration of the skin around her neck and arm-pits are suggestive of Acanthosis Nigricans. The most commonly associated condition with it is obesity.

Acanthosis nigricans is a dermatosis that manifests as an asymptomatic and symmetrical darkening of the skin. It is seen in the skin of intertriginous areas, in particular the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.

Obesity is the most common association with acanthosis nigricans and can regress with weight loss.

Disorders associated with acanthosis nigricans:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Diabetes
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Wilson syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gallbladder and bile duct cancer
  • Bladder cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

Skin condition Most commonly associated malignancy

Acanthosis palmaris Bronchial carcinoma

tracts

pancreatic islet cell adenoma
