questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts caudal regression syndrome.

The caudal regression syndrome is a rare malformation but is frequently associated with maternal diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.

It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants.

questions.text: What is the X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 9-month-old child?

choices.text: X-ray of the hands and wrist
X-ray of the elbow and hip

questions.solution:
The X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 9-month-old child is an X-ray of the shoulder.

The bone age of a child indicates his/her level of biological and structural maturity. Methods used for bone age estimation are Gruelisch–Pyle atlas (more common) and Tanner– Whitehouse method.

Bone age estimation
Age X-ray of choice
3 to 9 months X-ray shoulder
1 to 13 years Single film of X-ray hands and wrist
12 to 14 years X-ray elbow and hip

Note: There is overlap in the age ranges for X-rays of choice.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was referred to the ophthalmology OPD for decreased visual acuity. She described her vision as blurry with apparent flies floating in her field of vision. Fundoscopy revealed the following finding.  What is the CD4+T cell count at which majority of such cases occur?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy, is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. The majority of such cases occur in HIV-infected patients with a CD4+T cell count <50/μL.

CMV retinitis is a necrotic retinal infection that results in a painless irreversible vision loss. Patients may complain of blurred vision, floaters (described by patient as flies or spiders in the field of vision), and scintillations. It is usually bilateral and is characterized by perivascular hemorrhage and exudates in the retina (pizza pie appearance or scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance).

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV ganciclovir (3 weeks)
  • Maintenance - Oral valganciclovir (till CD4 count > 100/μl for 6months)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient came with complaints of progressive hearing loss. On thorough workup, it was diagnosed to be a clean case of otosclerosis. What would be the tympanic membrane finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is normal unless there is another co-existing pathology.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where one or more foci of irregularly spongy bone replace part of the normal bony otic capsule. Patients present with painless and progressive hearing loss, often the bilateral conductive type. They may hear better in noisy than in quiet environments (paracusis willisii).

The tympanic membrane is normal and mobile. A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Eustachian tube function is normal.

Pure tone audiometry shows a loss of air conduction, more for lower frequencies. Bone conduction is normal. In some cases, there may be a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies but greatest at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch. It is shown in the image below.

 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

The types of stapedial otosclerosis are:

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Circumferential
  • Biscuit type (thick plate)
  • Obliterative

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

Middle ear pathology (stapes footplate)

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida of 32 weeks presented with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus was tender and the cardiotocograph showed fetal distress. However, the mother is hemodynamically stable. What is the grade of placental abruption in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of grade 2 abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery. 

Depending upon the degree of placental abruption and its clinical effects, the cases are graded as follows:

Grade 1

Grade 2

Grade 3

Slight vaginal bleeding 

Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Minimal uterine tenderness

Uterine tenderness is  present

Marked uterine tenderness

Maternal BP and fibrinogen will be unaffected

Increased maternal pulse, but BP is maintained, fibrinogen levels may be decreased

 BP decreases, associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

FHS good

Fetal distress present

Fetal death occurs

 Maternal shock absent

Maternal shock absent

Pronounced shock

Note: In Grade 0 abruptio placenta, No clinical are present and it is usually diagnosed after delivery by inspecting the expelled placenta.

Management of abruptio placenta depends whether the patient is in labor or not.

  • If the patient is in labor, accelerate the process by amniotomy and oxytocin drip. Amniotomy initiates myometrial contraction and labor process and expedites delivery. It also reduces the risk of renal cortical necrosis and DIC
  • If the patient is not in labor and the if the there is continuous bleeding, then delivery is conducted either by induction of labor or cesarean section.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child develops these lesions over his face. How would you describe these lesions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows skin lesions characteristically appearing as shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules. These are seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a pox virus. The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen. It refers to dermatosis resulting from the spread of an infective agent. 

On microscopic examination, cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and molluscum bodies are seen. They are large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum. It is seen below.

 

Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid or curettage, and expression.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: According to WHO grading of brain tumors, which grade does medulloblastoma belong to?
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma corresponds to WHO grade IV.

It accounts for 20%of brain tumors in children. It occurs predominantly in children and exclusively in the cerebellum (by definition)

Neuronal and glial markers may be expressed, but the tumor is often largely undifferentiated and corresponds to WHO grade IV.

Dissemination through the CSF is a common complication.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with the findings shown in the image below. He also complained of pain in the upper and lower limbs. On examination, his BP was 160/100 mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. Serology was negative for ANCA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa.

The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN.

The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Other options:

1) Takayasu arteritis- It is a large vessel vasculitis. Also known as pulseless disease as it may be associated with weak upper extremity pulses.

2) Microscopic polyangiitis- It is a small vessel vasculitis. It is positive for p-ANCA. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without upper airway involvement.

3) Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis- It is frequently associated with hepatitis C. Circulating cryoglubulins and rheumatoid factor can be found in blood. Most common clinical manifestations are cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following segments in the cystometrogram represents the law of Laplace?
questions.solution:
In the given cystometrogram, the flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.

This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius. (P= 2T/R)

In the case of the blad­der, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL, and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL.

Cystometrogram (refer figure)

A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced (Ia);
  • A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced (Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered (II)

questions.text: The HPI (Human Poverty Index) used for developing countries is __________
questions.solution:
HPI-1 is used for developing countries and HPI – 2 is used for developed countries.

Human Poverty Index (HPI) measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.

The following picture table shows the components of HPI 1 and 2.

A decent standard of living

% of the population not using an improved water source 

% of children underweight for age

Deprivation of a decent standard of living

Social exclusion Not included as a dimension Long term unemployment rate
  • Range of HPI is from 0 to 100.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female came with complaints of a fast-growing painful gingival swelling lasting three weeks, associated with fever, fatigue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Intraoral examination showed a bluish-green swelling on the right posterior lower gingiva exhibiting necrotic surface. Which is the most probable type of AML associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given presentation is likely to be chloroma or myeloid sarcoma and is seen in AML M2/AML with maturation type.

Myeloid sarcoma (chloroma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, granulocytic sarcoma) is defined by the WHO as a tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation, occurring at extramedullary sites. It is Called "chloroma" due to peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase, fades in a few hours. 

Bones affected are orbit (most common), skull, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Other options:

Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.

Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia presents with the following symptoms. Which of them is not a Schneiderian first-rank symptom?
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is not a Schneiderian first-rank symptom of schizophrenia. It is one of the 4A’s of schizophrenia as described by Bleuler.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

1. Hallucination:

  • First-person hallucination (audible thoughts) - auditory hallucinations of the person’s own voice being spoken aloud.
  • Second-person hallucination (voices directly addressing the patient) - auditory hallucinations of 1 or more voices talking directly to the person. They can be persecutory, complimentary, or issue commands (command hallucination)
  • Third-person hallucination (voices speaking about the patient) - auditory hallucinations of 1 or more voices speaking about the person. The voice may deliver a running commentary or the voices maybe be arguing/discussing the person.

2. Thought phenomenon: 

  • Thought withdrawal-  thoughts being actively removed from a person’s mind.
  • Thought insertion- thoughts inserted into a person’s mind by some external agent.
  • Thought broadcasting- the sense that a person’s thoughts are experienced by others - the thoughts are made audible or may be experienced by others through telepathy.

3. Made phenomenon:

  • Made affect- feelings are imposed on that person by an external agent.
  • Made impulses or drives - an impulse for action is imposed on a person by some external agent.
  • Made volitional acts - a person’s actions are controlled by an external agent; the person is a passive participant in the action.

4. Delusional perception- the person attaches an abnormal significance/meaning to a normal perception, which leads to delusional interpretation. The most common delusion in schizophrenia is the delusion of persecution. These persecutory fears of the patient can range from transient doubts to profound convictions that people are plotting to have them tortured or killed.

5. Somatic passivity- tactile or visceral hallucinations that are thought to be imposed on a person's body by some external agent.

These symptoms are not specific to schizophrenia and may also be present in other psychiatric disorders.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with recurrent abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year with increased stool frequency. According to ROME IV criteria he was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome of the diarrhea-predominant type. Which neurotransmitter is likely to be associated with the disease process of this patient?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhea-predominant type (IBS-D) is serotonin (5-HT).

Serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells in the colon are increased in a subset of patients with IBS-D compared to healthy individuals. Serotonin may contribute to the postprandial symptoms of these patients and provide a rationale for the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this disorder.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A 37-year-old male with a history of recurrent painful oral aphthous ulcers that usually subside in about 10 days without leaving a scar and recurrent painful scrotal ulcers that heal with scarring has a positive pathergy test. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features of recurrent oral and genital ulcers along with a positive pathergy test are suggestive of Behcet's disease.

Behcet's syndrome is a vasculitic disorder that presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations and ocular involvement. It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder with a known association with HLA B*51. 

This syndrome commonly presents in young people, with males having more severe disease. These patients present with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers that are usually small and painful, painful genital ulcers, skin lesions (folliculitis, erythema nodosum, positive pathergy test, etc.), uveitis, arthritis/arthralgia, deep vein thromboses, etc.

Diagnostic Criteria of Behçet’s Syndrome:

Recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following:

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions
  • Positive Pathergy test

Pathergy reaction is a hypersensitivtiy reaction of the skin 24 to 48 hours following a prick with a needle. There is formation of papular or pustular nodules at the site of prick which is indicative of a positive test.

questions.text: Aliskiren is a ________
questions.solution: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. It is a competitive inhibitor of the active site of renin and the block conversion of angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I. It used in the treatment of hypertension. It is contraindicated in diabetic nephropathy, pregnancy, or renal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper arm and a history of a trivial fall a few days ago. His X-ray is given below. Which of the following is not a treatment modality for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is not a treatment modality used in the treatment of the above condition.
The given X-ray reveals a fracture running through a central cystic lesion situated on the proximal humeral metaphysis, and also shows a fallen fragment sign. This along with the clinical scenario (male within 2nd decade of life) is strongly suggestive of a unicameral bone cyst (simple bone cyst). 

Treatment of simple bone cyst:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions - serial observation with plain radiographs as lesions will regress following skeletal maturity
  • Larger lesions (at risk of pathologic fracture) and symptomatic lesions - 
    • Curettage 
    • Aspiration and injection using:
      • Corticosteroids
      • Bone marrow aspirate
      • Demineralized bone matrix
  • Pathological fractures -
    • Upper limb: managed conservatively as the fracture may initiate cyst healing
    • Lower limb: curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most strongly associated with a history of smoking?
questions.solution:
Periductal mastitis is strongly associated with a history of smoking. More than 90% of the affected individuals are smokers. 

Periductal mastitis is also called recurrent subareolar abscess or squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts or Zuska disease. In this condition, a relative deficiency of vitamin A associated with smoking or toxic substances in tobacco smoke alters the differentiation of the ductal epithelium.

Histologically, there is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts. Keratin shed from these cells is trapped and plugs (keratin plug) the ductal system, causing dilation and eventually rupture of the duct. This results in keratin spillage into the surrounding periductal tissue forming a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response.

It presents with a painful erythematous subareolar mass that clinically mimics bacterial abscess. It has a high recurrence rate.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary gland ducts is obstructed in this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition shown in the given image is a ranula. It is due to the obstruction of the duct of the sublingual salivary gland.

If the ducts of any salivary gland become obstructed, they can develop a retention cyst. If such cysts occur due to the obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland, it is called a ranula. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline. If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands, such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog.

It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination, the fluctuation test and transillumination test are positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialisation. Definitive management is the excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of the sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

 Note: Oral ranulas located on the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoid cyst.

questions.text: A baker uses artificial colours and flavour additives in his bakery goods. Which metalloprotein is responsible for the metabolism of these substances?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome P450 is involved in the metabolism of flavour/colour additives which are examples of xenobiotics.

Hydroxylation of xenobiotics is done by Cytochrome P450.

The members of the cytochrome P450 family generate Fe = O3+. This is a powerful oxidant that participates in the reduction and neutralization of a broad range of xenobiotics via the two-electron reduction of O2.

Related Pearl: Heme containing proteins

Protein Function
 Hemoglobin   Transport of oxygen in the blood
 Myoglobin   Storage of oxygen in muscle
 Cytochrome C   Involvement in the electron transport chain
 Cytochrome P450  Hydroxylation of xenobiotics
 Catalase  Degradation of hydrogen peroxide
 Tryptophan pyrrolase  Oxidation of tryptophan

questions.text: A 45-year- old labourer presented to the emergency with weakness in the right side of the body and slurred speech. His history showed that he followed a strict vegetarian diet. O/E he was afebrile, his BP was 160/100 mm Hg, and HR was 110/min. Routine investigations were normal except for raised homocysteine levels. Which of the following deficiencies is not responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia as given in the above clinical scenario.

All the following vitamin deficiencies - pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), folic acid, and cobalamin (B12) can cause hyperhomocysteinemia which can lead to stroke as given in the clinical scenario.

  • Vitamin B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine-β-synthase.
  • Vitamin B12 is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Due to a deficiency of vitamin B12, there is the failure of conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. Hence folate accumulates in the form of methyl tetrahydrofolate resulting in functional folate deficiency. 

Classic homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder of methionine metabolism, due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme will cause cysteine deficiency, hence cysteine needs to be supplemented in the diet.

Clinical features:

  • Affected children are initially asymptomatic. 
  • Ectopia lentis (subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Methionine supplementation is required in non-classical homocystinuria. It is due to impaired re-methylation of homocysteine to methionine. This can be caused by defective methionine synthase or reduced availability of two essential cofactors, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, and methylcobalamin.

Elevated homocysteine levels with low levels of methionine will be seen. Treatment includes methionine supplementation and administration of methyl folate, hydroxocobalamin, and betaine.

questions.text: A ligament is marked in red in the given image below. According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, the given ligament comes under which column?
questions.solution:
The given ligament marked in red is the posterior longitudinal ligament. It is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability: This was used to describe the classification of spinal injuries.

  • Anterior column:
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament
  • Middle column:
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • Posterior column
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament

The fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries i.e. there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage of the neural tissues.

The given image shows the three spinal columns:

questions.text: Which of the following are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the virus?
questions.solution:
The peplomers are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the viral envelope.

Structure of a virus has the following:

  • Nucleocapsid: The capsid with enclosed nucleic acid is known as Nucleocapsid.
  • Envelope: A lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation by a budding process through a cellular membrane.
  • Tegument: Proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid.

Note: Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent 
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
The scenario of a 16-year-old girl with absent secondary sexual characters, normal stature, with XX karyotype and high FSH and LH is suggestive of pure gonadal dysgenesis.

46 XX and 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis without the phenotype of Turner's syndrome (short stature, webbed neck) is described as pure gonadal dysgenesis. It is characterized by the presence of primary amenorrhea with or without normal secondary sexual characteristics. 

Option A: Testicular feminizing syndrome occurs in karyotype XY. Secondary sexual characters are present and the uterus is absent.

Option C: Kallmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. GnRH synthesis is reduced, therefore FSH and LH are low, and secondary sexual characters are absent.

Option D: Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and karyotype X0. Secondary sexual characters and the uterus is present, but the ovaries are streaked.

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 35 weeks of gestation underwent a pulmonary function test. Which of the following parameter is expected to be increased compared to her pre-pregnant levels?
questions.solution:
Tidal volume increases in pregnancy.

The changes in the respiratory system during pregnancy are:

Increase

Decrease

  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute ventilation
  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume

  • Vital capacity 

(Mnemonic: TIM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text: Which of the following substances mediates increased secretion of acid in the stomach when a person has a protein rich meal?
questions.solution:
When a meal rich in protein has been consumed, the increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach is likely due to gastrin. 

The peptides and amino acids have a special stimulatory effect on the gastric cells located in the pyloric antrum, causing the secretion of gastrin. This further increases the hydrochloric acid secretion. 

Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Distension of stomach
  • Peptides
  • Calcium
  • Increased vagal discharge

Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Gastric acid
  • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Somatostatin
  • Calcitonin

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A male patient came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft is suggestive of white piedra and the causative agent is Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types: white piedra and black piedra. 

White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii. It is characterized by the presence of soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is seen in the culture as nodules in the form of a sheath extending around the hair shaft. Arthroconidia and blastoconidia are seen.

Black piedra is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. It is caused by Piedraia hortae (option C). On microscopy, they appear as brown, thick-walled with septate hyphae and chlamydoconidia.

Shaving or cutting off the affected hair is useful in managing both black and white piedra. In black piedra, topical benzoic acid and terbinafine is helpful while topical antifungals, azoles, and allylamines can be useful in white piedra.

Other superficial mycoses and infectious organisms are Hortaea (Exophiala) werneckii (option B) causing tinea nigra. They cause lesions in the palm which appear dark brown to black in color. On Sabouraud agar, they appear as grey or black colonies. Skin scrapings reveal brownish branched septate hyphae and budding cells.

Tinea versicolor (Option D) or Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species like Malassezia globosa, Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic lesions are macules that are hypo or hyperpigmented on the chest, upper back, arms, or abdomen. Skin scrapings show yeast-like cells and short branching filaments.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who suffered myocardial infarction was given aspirin and another drug that acts by inhibiting thrombin-induced activation of platelets. The other drug given along with aspirin is _________
questions.solution:
The other drug given along with aspirin in patients with myocardial infarction is Vorapaxar. Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1(Protease Activated Receptor-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.  

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Eptifibatide is contraindicated in renal failure and tirofiban needs dose adjustment in cases of renal impairment.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar

Dipyridamole

questions.text: A plane mirror retinoscopy was performed on a 25-year-old male at 1-meter distance. The red reflex was found to be moving against the movement of the retinoscope. What is the inference of this test?
questions.solution:
Since the red reflex is moving against the retinoscope, the patient is having myopia more than 1D.

Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1m without cycloplegia:

  • No movement - myopia of 1D
  • With the movement - emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D
  • Against the movement - myopia more than 1D

questions.text: A juvenile delinquent was sentenced by the court to be placed in a center under the care of a doctor and psychiatrist. Which of the following fulfills this requirement?
questions.solution:
A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist and other trained personnel.

An orphanage or shelter home is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed.

Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis.

Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison. It is where boys > 16 years who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle are sent.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Improper suturing of complete perineal tears is the most common cause of rectovaginal fistula.

Rectovaginal fistulas occur most commonly due to obstetric causes such as perineal tears, obstructed labor, and instrumental deliveries. Other causes include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Lymphogranuloma venerum
  • Bartholinitis - rupture of an abscess into the rectum can cause a fistula
  • Diverticulitis 
  • Carcinoma cervix
  • Radiotherapy - can cause ulceration which can develop into a fistula

questions.text: You are an intern in the OPD seeing a 3-year-old female child with severe disfigurement and photosensitivity. On examination, skin thickening and brownish teeth are seen. Urine examination reveals increased uroporphyrin 1.  What condition is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the increased levels of uroporphyrin 1 suggest that she is suffering from congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also known as Gunther's disease.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with severe photosensitivity from birth, skin thickening, hypo and hyperpigmentation of the skin, and sun-exposed areas prone to infection and disfigurement. Hypertrichosis of the face and limbs may be seen. The skin over sun-exposed areas develops bullae and vesicles which can rupture and get infected. Brownish teeth may be seen due to the deposition of porphyrins. Hemolysis and splenomegaly may be seen.

Laboratory values show increased levels of urinary, fecal, and red cell uroporphyrin 1.

Treatment includes transfusions for treating the anemia, and splenectomy to reduce the hemolysis. Bacterial infections should be treated and protection from sunlight should be done.

Other options:

Option A: Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by the deficiency of Ferrochetalase and presents with photosensitivity.

Option B: Hereditary coproporphyria is due to deficient coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX) and presents with abdominal pain, photosensitivity, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Option C: X-linked sideroblastic anemia is caused by deficient δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS 2) and manifests as anemia.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Variegate porphyria
(VP)
Protoporphyrinogen oxidase
(PPOX)

(EPP)

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman presented with pain and swelling in the left shoulder for 1 month. The X-ray showed complete destruction of the humeral head. Arthrocentesis yielded a hemorrhagic noninflammatory fluid. The synovial fluid culture was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Milwaukee's shoulder. 

It is a rapidly progressive destructive osteoarthritis with extensive bone loss, such that the whole head of the humerus disappears. There is the rapid destruction of the rotator cuff and the glenohumeral joint.

It is characterized by Intraarticular or periarticular hydroxyapatite crystals.

Synovial fluid can be stained by alizarin red staining. It is often hemorrhagic with low cellularity (<2000 leucocytes/mL) cells.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A young girl presented with bilateral visual loss, peripheral neuropathy, and postural tremors. The fundus examination showed optic atrophy. Pedigree chart of the disease is given below. What is the pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.

The clinical features and inheritance pattern is suggestive of Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, which is characterized by bilateral visual loss, severe optic atrophy, psychiatric symptoms, peripheral neuropathy, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and sometimes white matter lesions. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy is a prototype of mitochondrial inheritance. It occurs due to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve.

Mitochondrial inheritance is caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome. Inheritance is exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization. Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease. 

Features of mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Mutation in the mitochondrial gene is either due to deletion or point mutation.
  • Mitochondrial defect in the mother can affect both the male and female gender but a father with a mitochondrial defect cannot pass it to the next generation. 
  • A cell can have both normal and abnormal mitochondrial genomes, and this phenomenon is referred to as heteroplasmy.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
  • These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)

Disease

Features

Ophthalmoplegia

Pigmentary retinopathy

Cardiomyopathy

L: Leigh disease

Subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy

Acute or subacute vision loss due to B/L optic atrophy

Cerebellar ataxia

Hyperreflexia

Babinski sign

Psychiatric symptoms

Peripheral neuropathy

Cardiac conduction abnormalities

Some have white matter lesions

M: MELAS

Mitochondrial myopathy

Encephalopathy

(MERRF) Myoclonic epilepsy, ragged red fibers in muscle, ataxia, sensorineural deafness

N: NARP (2 clinical patterns)

1. Neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, dementia

2. Severe infantile encephalopathy with lesions in basal ganglia

questions.text: A 30-year-old nullipara with a desire to conceive presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. UPT is negative. Investigations indicate hyperprolactinemia. What is the drug of choice for clinical management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for clinical management of this patient would be bromocriptine.

Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid and a short-acting dopamine receptor agonist. Due to its short-term action, it is preferred when pregnancy is desired.

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity. It effectively suppresses PRL secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose.

questions.text: A young man met with a bike accident. He lost all his motor, sensory, and autonomic functions of the spinal cord below the level of the lesion. However, vibration and position sensations are preserved. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the patient is Anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome. 

ASA infarct typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion. Since the dorsal column is located in the posterior or dorsal aspect of the spinal cord, it is spared.

Other options:

Central cord syndrome:

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome produces arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness and a “dissociated” sensory loss, meaning loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution), in contrast to the preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in these regions.

Foramen magnum syndrome:

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described and manifests as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The pattern of the weakness may begin in any of the limbs. 

Brown–Sequard Syndrome: ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract) and loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column), with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract) one or two levels below the lesion

Related Pearl: Ascending tracts of spinal cord

Second-order neurons from the posterior gray column crossover to the opposite side and ascend as anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract >

questions.text: 6 types of DNA- A, B, C, D, E, and Z, have been identified. Which statement is not true respective to the type of DNA?

choices.text: B-DNA which is physiologically  the most common form
A-DNA is found in conditions with low humidity and high salt concentration
B-DNA is found in conditions of high salt concentration and low humidity

questions.solution:
B-DNA is found in conditions with high humidity and low salt concentration.

There are 6 types of DNA- A, B, C, D, E, and Z. All are right-handed except Z-DNA.

A-DNA is found in conditions with low humidity and high salt concentration.

B-DNA which is the physiologically most common form is found in conditions with high humidity and low salt concentration.

Z-DNA is a left-handed double helix in the 5' end of the chromosome and has a phosphodiester backbone in a zigzag form.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a radical neck dissection for carcinoma of the buccal mucosa. During the procedure, he inadvertently injured the middle trunk of the brachial plexus. Which of the following nerve functions can be impaired?
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve function can be impaired due to an injury to the middle trunk of the brachial plexus.

The middle trunk is the continuation of the C7 root. Among the given nerves, the thoracodorsal nerve has the root values of C6, C7, and C8. 

The thoracodorsal nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension and medial rotation of the humerus.

Option A: Medial pectoral nerve is a branch of the medial cord. It has the root values of C8 and T1.

Options B and C: Nerve to subclavius and suprascapular nerve are branches from the upper trunk. They both have the root values of C5 and C6. 

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C7)

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)
Medial cord (UM4)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8,T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8,T1)
