Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: Which type of FSGS has relatively a good prognosis?
questions.solution:
The tip variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has a relatively good prognosis.

FSGS is characterized by a sclerosis of a portion of the capillary tuft in the glomeruli. It frequently manifests as the acute or subacute onset of nephrotic syndrome or non-nephrotic proteinuria. Hypertension, microscopic hematuria, and azotemia are commonly present when the disease is first clinically recognized.

There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant (poor prognosis)
  • Glomerular tip variant (good prognosis)
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified variant (most common)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has bilateral optic atrophy with diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wolfram syndrome. It is due to WFS1 gene mutation. 

The presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years; diabetes mellitus is typically the first manifestation, followed by visual problems. It has a poor prognosis. 

Clinical features are: (DIDMOAD) 

  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Optic atrophy
  • Deafness (sensorineural type) 

Option A: Kjer's optic neuropathy is an autosomal dominant condition. It presents with vision loss in early childhood and no significant systemic features.

Option B: Behr syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Clinical features include optic atrophy, pyramidal tract signs, ataxia, intellectual disability, urinary incontinence, and pes cavus

Option D: Leber's congenital amaurosis is an autosomal recessive condition. It usually presents with significant vision loss in infancy and nystagmus.

questions.text: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is ________
questions.solution:
Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is allodynia.

Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the skin pain endings by local tissue products released due to burns — histamine, prostaglandins, and others.

Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the OPD with decreased vision. He also gave a history of tremors and dysarthria for 2 months now. After a thorough examination, the physician suspects Wilson's disease. Which is the most sensitive and accurate test for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The most sensitive and accurate test in diagnosing Wilson's disease is measuring the hepatic copper content.

The diagnosis of Wilson's disease is based on the following:

  • Increased 24-hour urinary excretion of copper (the most specific screening test)
  • Increase in hepatic copper content (the most sensitive and accurate test)
  • A decrease in serum ceruloplasmin
  • Kayser–Fleischer rings 
  • Genetic testing for mutations in the ATP7B gene
 
Serum copper levels are of no diagnostic use since they may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of the disease.

questions.text: Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in abetalipoproteinemia?
questions.solution:
In Abetalipoproteinemia, early death can be prevented by the administration of large doses of fat-soluble vitamins, particularly vitamin E.

Abetalipoproteinemia is due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons and VLDLs in the intestine and liver, respectively.

Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Acanthocytes or spur cells are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and surface distribution which are seen in abetalipoproteinemia.

Other options : 

The reason why vitamin E is used is that it helps in restoring and producing lipoproteins in the body. Other vitamins given in the options will not play such a role and hence have no beneficial effects in abetalipoproteinemia.

questions.text: An enthusiastic researcher found a positive correlation between the incidence of respiratory problems and the rising pollution in a district. He collected data from the district hospitals and the pollution control board. What is the type of study done here?
questions.solution:
The study described above is an example of an ecological study.

The ecological study is a type of analytical study that analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called correlational study, and it uses population as a unit of study.

In the given scenario, the study was done with the district population, from which we can infer that the population was taken as the unit of the study. Also, the study was done to correlate the incidence of respiratory problems and pollution in the existing community.

Type of epidemiological study Unit of study

Analytical studies (hypothesis testing)

    
  • Cohort study/ Follow up study
 Individual
  • Case-control study
 Individual
  • Cross-sectional study/ Prevalence study
 Individual
  • Ecological study/ Correlational study
 Population

Experimental studies (hypothesis confirmation)

  
  • Randomized control trial/ Clinical trials
 Patients
  • Field trial
 Healthy people
  • Community trial
 Community

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A patient who underwent resection of prostate developed TUR syndrome. Which of the following is not likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The transurethral resection (TUR) syndrome occurs as a complication of the transurethral resection of prostate (TURP) due to the prolonged use of hypotonic irrigation fluid. Bradycardia is seen in this syndrome, not tachycardia.

Prolonged use of hypotonic irrigation fluid, results in fluid overload, and dilutional hyponatremia causing water intoxication also known as transurethral resection (TUR) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to:

  • Hyponatremia- may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 
  • Hypertension
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Bradycardia

Management- treatment consists of fluid restriction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic male was brought to the emergency department in a semiconscious state with deep breaths. His RBG was 600 mg% and the Rothera's test was positive. Which of the following type of Oxygen-Hb dissociation curves is expected to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the clinical scenario has been suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. Hence, a shift to the right (D) of the ODC curve is expected in this patient.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favours O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

Interpretation of the curves:

  • The curve marked 'A' is the ODC curve for myoglobin. It assumes the shape of a rectangular hyperbola.
  • The curve marked 'C' is the normal ODC curve and the curves 'B' and 'D' are the shift of the normal curve to left and right respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is a synonym of Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome?
questions.solution:
Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome is a synonym for occult filariasis.

It occurs due to hypersensitivity reaction to microfilarial antigens, and not directly due to lymphatic involvement. The clinical features include massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, and mild pulmonary symptoms. However, the classical features of lymphatic filariasis are absent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department after a suicide attempt in which an unknown quantity of metformin was ingested. On biochemical examination, her lactate levels are raised. What is the type of lactic acidosis encountered here?
questions.solution:
Metformin (biguanide) toxicity encountered here is a Type B lactic acidosis.

Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of L-lactic acidosis are:

  • Type A - This occurs secondary to poor tissue perfusion. The conditions include shock, cardiac failure, severe anemia, carbon monoxide, or cyanide toxicity.
  • Type B - This type of lactic acidosis occurs in aerobic disorders. It can occur secondary to malignancies, renal failure, hepatic failure, drugs like metformin, ethanol, ethylene glycol, and methanol, diabetes mellitus, seizures, Severe malaria/ cholera etc .

Note: A D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis that occurs in patients with short bowel syndrome, post-jejunoileal bypass, or intestinal obstruction. This is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: The lepidic growth pattern in histology is seen in which of the following epithelial lung tumors?
questions.solution:
Histologically lepidic growth patterns are seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

It refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resembles butterflies resting on a fence.

Tumors of 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma).

Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Tumor cells are positive for mucin and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1).

It is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells. It is usually located peripherally (it arises from terminal bronchiole).  Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. On examination, a new onset diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space, and Traube's sign is positive. A diagnosis of acute severe aortic regurgitation is made. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement. 

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Aortic regurgitation (AR). 

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease, or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.

The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.

questions.text: Which theory of cholesteatoma deals with the concept of epithelial invasion?
questions.solution:
Habermann’s theory of cholesteatoma deals with the concept of epithelial invasion.

The epithelium from the meatal surface grows into the middle ear through a pre-existing perforation. The perforation is commonly a marginal type, where the part of the annulus tympanicus has already been destroyed.

Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types: Congenital & Acquired.

Congenital cholesteatoma can be explained by the presence of congenital cell rests within the middle ear and other parts of the temporal bone.

Acquired cholesteatoma is explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and Eustachian tube drainage or the tympanic membrane epithelium.

The theories put forth are given in the pearl that follows:

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent total hip replacement surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally severed a nerve. Post-operatively, the patient had a gluteus maximus lurch and wasting of the muscle. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the inferior gluteal nerve is likely to be injured.

The gluteus maximus is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. Injury to the nerve causes atrophy of the muscle causing weakness in the extension of the thigh. The patients typically have a gluteus maximus lurch.

The gluteus maximus may be tested by extension of the hip against resistance, in the supine or prone position.

questions.text: Yohimbine is a _________
questions.solution:
Yohimbine is a competitive antagonist that is selective for α2 receptors.

It is an indolealkylamine alkaloid found in the bark of the Pausinystalia yohimbe tree and the root of Rauwolfia. Yohimbine easily penetrates the central nervous system (CNS), where it increases blood pressure and heart rate, enhances motor activity, and can cause tremors.

Other option:

Option A: Selective alpha 1 receptor agonist is phenylephrine.

Option B: Selective alpha 2 receptor agonist is clonidine.

Option D: Selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist are prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin, alfuzosin, tamsulosin.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: The usage of metformin in the individuals at the risk of developing diabetes mellitus reduces the incidence of the disease by _______
questions.solution:
The use of metformin in preventing diabetes mellitus in people with high risk reduces the incidence by 25-31%.

Lifestyle modification for preventing type 2 diabetes in people of high risk reduces the incidence by 35-58%.

questions.text: A party was attended by 110 people out of which, 40 did not eat fruit salad. Among the rest of those who ate fruit salad, 55 developed food poisoning. What is the attack rate?
questions.solution:
The attack rate is calculated by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of new cases is 55 and the total number of those at risk is 70 as they ate the fruit salad.

Therefore attack rate = 55/70 X 100 = 78.6%.

 Attack rate is an incidence rate. It is used only when the population is exposed to risk for a limited period.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: Which of the following is a placebo?

choices.text: Herbal medication with no effect known

questions.solution:
Sham surgery sometimes called placebo surgery involves an active intervention where the patient undergoes all the procedures related to the surgery except the final corrective (therapeutic) step. Though there are controversies surrounding the use of sham surgery mainly due to ethical issues, it still can be considered as a placebo in surgical intervention. 

Physiotherapy and cognitive behavioral therapy are active interventions with known effects. 

A placebo should be an inert material with exactly the same physical appearance, odor, consistency as the active dosage form. A herbal medication with no effect known does not necessarily fit in the exact definition of placebo.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital due to an exacerbation of her symptoms. Which of the following sign shown in the MRI image below is a characteristic sign of this disease?
questions.solution:
The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers.

Dawson's fingers are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are a characteristic feature of multiple sclerosis and presents as T2 hyperintensities.

MRI is the imaging of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity.

Other options:

  • Hot cross bun sign is a finding in the pons, seen in Multiple system atrophy.
  • Molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome.
  • The Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber Syndrome.

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. 

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction 

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of epithelial metaplasia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous metaplasia. It is commonly seen in the respiratory tract of smokers. 

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways

Squamous metaplasia: It is seen in chronic smoking. The normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells of the trachea and bronchi are replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.

Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.

Salivary glands, pancreas, bile ducts

Squamous metaplasia: The presence of stones in the excretory duct may trigger metaplasia, where the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Cervix

Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Esophagus

Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus).
Muscle

Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Image showing squamous metaplasia in endocervical glands of the cervix.

The image below depicts the histopathology of Barret's esophagus, showing the internalized epithelium with goblet cells as opposed to the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus and pseudostratified columnar epithelium of the fundus of the stomach. The submucosa displays an infiltrate including lymphocytes and plasma cells, constituting an underlying chronic inflammation.

questions.text: An intern during his presentation on CPR was asked to demonstrate chest compressions and rescue breaths over a mannequin in the case of children. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths that should be given by the intern in case of a single-rescuer?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of infants and children, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single-rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present. In adults, the ratio is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

  • In infants and children, the depth of compression should be at least one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest which is about 5 cm in children and 4 cm in infants.
  • The compression rate should be 100-120/minute.
  • Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions (10 seconds or less).
  • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or earlier if fatigued.
  • Avoid excessive ventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to inhibit swarming?
questions.solution:
Factor V is not used to inhibit swarming. It is responsible for satellitism in H.influenza

Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of Agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

Swarming on culture media is exhibited by the following:

  • Gram-positive bacilli: Clostridium tetani, Bacillus cereus
  • Gram-negative bacilli: Proteus mirabilis, Proteus vulgaris
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a gram-negative halophilic bacteria

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the development of the pancreas is false?

choices.text: Inferior part of the head develops from the ventral pancreatic bud
Accessory duct develops from the dorsal pancreatic duct
Superior part of the head develops from the dorsal pancreatic bud
The uncinate process develops from the dorsal pancreatic bud

questions.solution:
The uncinate process develops from the ventral pancreatic bud.

The pancreas develops from two buds, dorsal and ventral, originating from the endodermal lining of the duodenum. When the duodenum rotates and becomes C-shaped, the ventral bud gets positioned immediately below and behind the dorsal bud. This is followed by the fusion of the parenchyma and the duct systems of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds.

The parenchyma of the pancreas:

  • Ventral pancreatic bud forms the lower part of the head and uncinate process.
  • Dorsal pancreatic bud forms the upper part of the head, neck, body, and tail.

Pancreatic ducts

  • The main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of ventral bud (proximal part), oblique cross-communication between the 2 ducts (middle part), and the duct of dorsal bud (distal part).
  • The accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct.

The image given below shows the development of pancreas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma located in close proximity to the GE junction. The consultant decides to treat the tumor surgically. According to Siewert classification, what type of tumors are to be treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Siewert Type III tumors are be treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma.

Note: Siewert types I and II tumors are treated similar to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. What is the reflex elicited in the process?
questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex.

Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven.

It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost/carboprost.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she came back with fever, tachycardia, and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis.

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Most common clinical presentation is headache with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focal deficits.

Investigations:

  • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
  • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

Option A: Subarachnoid hemorrhage - As there are no focal deficits, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option B: Meningitis - The patient would have presented with neck rigidity or photophobia. Moreover, the presence of early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

Option C: Acute migraine - It does not present with seizures.

questions.text: An anesthetist in an OT after giving a neuraxial block uses a modified Bromage scale to assess the quality of the motor block. Which of the following motor fibers will be assessed by anesthetist using this scale?
questions.solution:
Lumbosacral motor fibers will be assessed by anesthetist using modified Bromage scale.

Adequacy of the motor block after neuraxial anesthesia can be assessed by various ways,

The modified Bromage scale is most commonly used one but this scale assess the adequacy of block of lumbosacral motor fibers only.

Electromyography and pulmonary function tests (spirometry) have been used to measure abdominal and thoracic motor function, but these are neither practical nor specific.

Related Pearl: Modified Bromage scale

0: No motor block

1: Inability to raise the extended leg; Able to move knees and feet

2: Inability to raise the extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet

3: Complete block of motor limb

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with abdominal pain with a history of hematemesis. Upper GI endoscopy reveals peptic ulcer disease with a black spot in the ulcer crater. According to Forrest Classification, the endoscopic findings of this ulcer belongs to _________
questions.solution:
According to Forrest Classification, Peptic Ulcer with black spot belongs to Grade 2c. Forrest classification is used to asses rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease. 

Forrest classification for PU bleeding: 

Stage Characteristics Rebleeding Risk
Ia Jet arterial bleeding High
Ib Oozing High
IIa Visible vessel High
IIb Adherent clot Intermediate
IIc Black spot in ulcer crater Low
III Clean, non-bleeding ulcer bed Low

questions.text: In an asthma patient, drug zafirlukast relieves asthmatic symptoms by acting as a __________
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. They are competitive antagonists of the cysLT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

Option A: Omalizumab is an Anti-IgE receptor used in asthma.

Option B: Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer.

Option D: Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with complains of pain and inability to move the limb following a fall on an outstretched hand. A diagnosis of anterior shoulder dislocation was made. The following method of reduction is performed. What is the step 'C' performed in the given technique?
questions.solution:
The shown maneuver above is Kocher's technique of anterior shoulder reduction, The step 'C' here signifies Adduction being done.

The order of steps in Kocher's maneuver is traction, external rotation, adduction, medial rotation (TEAM) shown as steps A, B, C, and D respectively.

Other maneuvers used in anterior dislocation of the shoulder include:

  • Stimson’s gravity method: The patient is made to lie prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. A weight may be attached to the elbow or wrist. The shoulder may reduce after 15-20 minutes. 
  • Hippocratic method (traction counter-traction): Gently increasing traction is applied to the arm with the shoulder in slight abduction.  Counter-traction is applied with the heel in the axilla.

Anterior dislocation is the most common among shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hands.The clinical features include severe pain and the patient usually supports his dislocated arm with the opposite arm. 

The following findings are seen on examination:

  • Flattening of the normal shoulder contour.
  • A displaced head can be felt as a fullness below the clavicle.
  • Dugas test and Hamilton ruler test are positive. 

X-ray findings in anterior shoulder dislocation

Hill Sach's lesion is due to impingement of glenoid labrum into the humeral head, causing posterolateral depression.

Bankart lesion is due to stripping of the glenoid labrum from the glenoid cavity as the head dislocates. It sometimes may be associated with bony avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid rim as seen in this image.

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to Gold's criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
The expected pulmonary function test (PFT) values in this patient are FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80%.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of atleast one short acting inhaled bronchodilator.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy is addicted to marijuana and has developed psychosis now. Which of the following endogenous chemical substances in the human body is similar to the psychoactive principle of marijuana?
questions.solution:
The psychoactive principle in marijuana is delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol. Anandamide is the endogenous chemical substance in the human body akin to this and acts on the cannabinoid receptor (CB1).

Two types of endocannabinoids have been identified:

  • 2-arachidonyl glycerol
  • Anandamide

The cannabinoid receptors are G protein-coupled receptors located predominantly in the presynaptic nerve terminals.

  • The CB1 receptor is located in the central nervous system. Activation of CB1 receptor results in euphoria and alleviation of pain (anti-nociceptive effect).
  • The CB2 receptor is located mainly in the periphery and their activation does not have a euphoric effect.

The endogenous cannabinoid system is a potential target for use in the treatment of chronic pain.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake.

NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value multiplied by 100.

1 gram of protein is equivalent to 6.25 g of nitrogen. The NPU value of a dietary protein and the protein requirement of the individual are inversely related to each other. The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Other options:

Option A: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the ratio of milligrams of digestible dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the dietary protein to the milligrams of the same dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the reference protein. 

Option C: The biological value is calculated as the amount of nitrogen used for tissue formation divided by the nitrogen absorbed from food expressed in percentage. It is a reflection of essential amino acid supplied and a measure of protein quality. 

Option D: The amino acid score refers to the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein. It is calculated as the percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed to have pheochromocytoma of the sympathetic chain in the posterior mediastinum. The cardiothoracic surgeon has planned to remove it by video-assisted thoracic surgery. During the procedure, which of the following structures is least likely to be encountered by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
As per the clinical scenario, the tumour is located in the posterior mediastinum. Hence, during the procedure, the surgeon would not encounter inferior vena cava which is located anteriorly in the middle mediastinum.

Descending thoracic aorta, oesophagus and thoracic duct are all located in the posterior mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum

Major contents of thoracic cavity
Superior mediastinum
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thoracic duct
  • Thymus
  • Vessels-
    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Roots of great vessels
    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Esophagus
  • Vagus nerve
  • Azygos vein
  • Hemiazygos vein

questions.text: During an autopsy of a man with a suspected case of poisoning, you observe the presence of a bitter almond odor. Which of the following electron transport chain (ETC) complexes may have been inhibited by this poison?
questions.solution:
Complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) is blocked by cyanide, which has a characteristic bitter almond odor in case of poisoning.

Complexes of ETC   Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin A, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL (British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

The following image shows different compounds inhibiting the different components in an electron transport chain.

Related Pearl: Characteristic Odor of Toxins

Odor

Toxins

Garlic odor

 

Arsenic, phosphorous, malathion, thallium carbonate

Odorless

Thallium sulfate (most common), thallium oxide

Garlic odor or rotten fish

Zinc phosphide

Odor of burnt rope

Cannabis

Phenolic odor

Carbolic acid
Smell of bitter almonds Cyanide
Fruity odor Ethyl alcohol
Rotten egg Hydrogen sulphide
Smell of kerosene Organophosphorous

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic CT appearance seen in patients with acute subdural hematoma?
questions.solution:
A crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines on axial CT is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
  • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections
  • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
  • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

A lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that does not cross suture lines on axial CT is suggestive of an epidural hemorrhage.

The image given below shows a subdural hematoma with a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion on CT:

 

The image given below is that of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage seen on CT:

 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the regions marked in blue?
questions.solution:
The given region is the suboccipital triangle. It does not contain the occipital artery.

The suboccipital triangle is bounded by:

  • Superomedially - rectus capitis posterior major
  • Superolaterally - obliquus capitis superior
  • Inferiorolaterally - obliquus capitis inferior
  • Roof - dense adipose tissue deep to semispinalis capitis, longissimus capitis muscle, and sometimes splenius capitis.
  • Floor -posterior atlantooccipital membrane and the posterior arch of the atlas.
  • Contents: 
    • 3rd part of the vertebral artery
    • suboccipital nerve (dorsal ramus of C1)
    • suboccipital venous plexus.

Note: The suboccipital triangle is clinically important in posterior cervical surgeries, as it is an anatomical landmark to identify the vertebral artery.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of taking medications for asthma, now presents with obesity, short stature, round face, and abdominal striae. What could be the most common cause of the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The probable cause, in this case, is Exogenous glucocorticoids.

History of asthma suggests that patient had been on exogenous steroids (inhaled/systemic) for long term management of severe asthma. The presenting features with a round face (moon facies), short stature, along with obesity and purple skin striae suggest a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome and the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. History of asthma suggests, the patient was administered long term exogenous (inhaled/systemic) steroids.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure of excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features in children

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A resident in the anatomy department is interested in studying the types of epithelial cells. Under microscopy, the following epithelium is seen. Which part of the female genitourinary tract is also lined by the epithelium depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The epithelium shown in the above image is the simple cuboidal epithelium. The ovary is also lined by this type of epithelium. 

The part of the genital tract and its corresponding epithelium are given below.

Part of the female genital tract  Lining epithelium
Ovary

Simple cuboidal
Fallopian tube Ciliated columnar
Endometrium

Ciliated cuboidal (before puberty)

Predominantly columnar (thereafter)
Endocervix Columnar epithelium
Ectocervix Non- keratinized stratified squamous
Vagina Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: In a study of a group of 40 people, a physiologist is studying the pacemaker actions of the sinoatrial node and the action potentials of each one of them were plotted in the graph given below. The ion channels predominantly responsible for the phase 0 marked in the graph is?
questions.solution:
The ion channels predominantly responsible for phase 0 marked in the graph is the L-type calcium channels. 

The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA (sinoatrial) node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to-60 millivolts. Phases of this potential are: 

  • Phase 0 - Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3 - Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate. 

Clinical aspect:

i) Vagal stimulation activates the cholinergic fibres to the SAN and leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by depolarizing effect of funny Na+ (If) channel on M2 receptor stimulation. There is also decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) causing the decreased firing of the T-type Ca2+ channel. Similar action is seen upon administering digitalis. 

ii) The frequency of SA node discharge is increased when the temperature rises. Thus, fever is usually associated with tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous lesions are associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with celiac disease.

These lesions include intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks. Patients with Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) also have an associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease).

The single best screening test for celiac disease is tissue transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) which has a sensitivity of about 98% & specificity of about 95%.

A gluten‐free diet is the cornerstone of long‐term dermatitis herpetiformis management. This also treats the associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (GSE) and may decrease the long‐term risk of lymphoma. Dapsone and related sulphonamide drugs have proven highly effective, suppressing pruritus within days of treatment.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: Naglazyme is used for treating patients with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome/MPS VI is caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase B enzyme whose gene locus is on chromosome 5. Preservation of intelligence is the feature of this syndrome. It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Naglazyme is used as an enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text: A known HIV-positive patient presents with dry cough and dyspnea. The chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial pneumonia with pneumatoceles. Special staining of the bronchoalveolar lavage sample shows the following picture. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the staining image are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The most likely causative organism is Pneumocystis jirovecii.

The special staining used here is Gomori’s methamine silver staining. On special staining, the cysts of P. jirovecii resemble black-coloured crushed ping pong balls.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive or productive of only scant amounts of white sputum. The chest X-ray is either normal or shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

 

 

The standard treatment for PCP is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is recommended for HIV patients with CD4<200/mm3.

questions.text: A young woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder is refractory to first-line antidepressant therapy. The psychiatrist now decides to prescribe a recently approved NMDA antagonist. Which of the following was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Esketamine is an NMDA antagonist recently approved for the treatment of treatment-resistant depression.

Esketamine is a non-selective, non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, an ionotropic glutamate receptor. Though the exact mechanism by which it acts as an antidepressant is unknown, a single dose of intranasal Esketamine has shown to have short-term antidepressant efficacy suggesting a possible use in suicidality.

Option A: Brexanolone has GABAA modulatory action. It is given via intravenous route for post-partum depression.

Option C: Lurasidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist at dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5-HT2A) receptors. It is approved for use in depressive episodes in bipolar disorder.

Option D: Lemborexant is an orexin receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adult patients with insomnia.

Functional imaging of individuals with major depression has pinpointed excessive metabolic activity in Brodmann area 25, the subgenual prefrontal cortex, a brain region that connects to the amygdala and is thought to play a critical role in the processing of emotion-related information. This increased metabolic activity reverses with successful antidepressant treatment.

questions.text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta or hypernasality of speech will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.

It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. The defect is the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities.

Common causes are:

  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Congenitally short soft palate
  • Submucous palate
  • Large nasopharynx
  • Cleft of soft palate
  • Paralysis of soft palate
  • Post adenoidectomy
  • Oronasal fistula
  • Familial speech pattern
  • Habitual speech pattern.

NOTE:

  • Clausa = Close; closed nose and nasopharynx
  • Aperta = Open/aperture; abnormally open nose and nasopharynx

questions.text: Which is not true regarding the given image?

choices.text: Circular ring in the proximal esophagus

questions.solution:
The given image shows Schatzki’s ring which is a circular ring seen in the distal esophagus.

  • It is usually present at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • The cause is obscure but it is strongly associated with reflux disease.
  • It may be associated with dysphagia and respond to dilatation along with medical anti-reflux therapy.

questions.text: The pediatrician refers the child shown below for dermatology and ophthalmology opinions. Oculocutaneous albinism is suspected. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Oculocutaneous albinism is not due to tryptophan deficiency but is due to tyrosinase deficiency.

It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye. Ophthalmological anomalies are also noted. It is caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis, but melanocytes are normally present and distributed.

It is caused by mutations in TYR, encoding the tyrosinase gene.

Significant photophobia may be present. Iris translucency is demonstrable by slit-lamp examination.

Sun protection is mandatory to avoid skin sunburns and skin cancers with a special emphasis on patients living in high UV risk environments. Early referral to an ophthalmologist is mandatory. Dark glasses are important to protect the eyes and prevent photophobia.

questions.text: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth of coarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.

Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is ≥8. Moderate to severe hirsutism is present if the score is ≥15.

Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.

questions.text: A concerned mother brought her daughter to the clinic for evaluation of symptoms that have worsened in the last few weeks. The daughter frequently wakes up at night with severe headaches and vomiting. She has also been having some difficulty walking. On examination, ataxia and multiple cranial nerve palsies are noted.  Imaging is suggestive of a brainstem tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRI given shows a diffuse, infiltrating pontine lesion. Multiple cranial nerve dysfunctions, cerebellar signs, motor weakness, and features of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are all strongly suggestive of a pontine glioma.

These are not amenable for surgical resection. The standard approach is radiation therapy. The prognosis is very poor.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodiffusion tests represents single diffusion in one dimension?
questions.solution:
Single diffusion in one dimension is called the Oudin procedure. Immunodiffusion employs antigen-antibody precipitation in gel medium rather than liquid and has several advantages. 

  • Distint line of precipitation which is stable and can be stained seperately
  • Able to detect the number of different antigens, as individual antigens produce a distinct line of precipitation
  • Analyse the identity and non-identity between different antigens

Different types of immunodiffusion:

  • Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure
  • Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure
  • Single diffusion in two dimensions - Radial immunodiffusion/Mancini procedure : This method has been used for the estimation of the immunoglobulin classes in sera and for screening sera for antibodies to influenza viruses
  • Double diffusion in two dimensions - Ouchterlony procedure : A special variety of double diffusion in two dimensions is the Elek test for toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. When diphtheria bacilli are streaked at right angles to a filter paper strip carrying the antitoxin implanted on a plate of suitable medium, arrowhead-shaped lines of precipitation appear on incubation, if the bacillus is toxigenic.

The images given below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the efficacy of oral contraceptive pills. Out of 100 women who took the pills, 10 women became pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl Index?
questions.solution:
The Pearl index is calculated to be 5 per hundred woman years.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this scenario, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10.

There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

We arrive at this: Pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per hundred woman-years

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels does not take part in the arterial anastomosis formed in this region of femur?
questions.solution:
The part of the femur that is pointed out in the given image is the lesser trochanter. The cruciate anastomosis is formed in this region. The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of the cruciate anastomosis.

Cruciate anastomosis:

It lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:

  • Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
  • Ascending branch of the first perforating artery

Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds or gunshot wounds) can result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following composition of alkaline solution (per 280ml of water) is used in atrophic rhinitis to remove the crusts?

choices.text: Soda bicarbonate 2 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Calcium chloride 2 parts
Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Calcium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Magnesium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Potassium chloride 2 parts

questions.solution:
The composition of alkaline solution is Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.

It is used to irrigate the nasal cavities. It loosens the crusts and helps in its removal.

Other treatment options:

  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Estradiol spray
  • Submucosal placental extract
  • Local antibiotics
  • Potassium iodide
  • Systemic use of streptomycin

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was diagnosed with constipation and was started on senna laxatives. After 5 months, the patient came to the hospital with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. The colonoscopy of the patient is shown. The diagnosis of this patient is ____________
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a black pigmentation of colonic mucosa that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coil.

As the laxative travels down the intestinal tract, it remains in its inactive form until it reaches the large intestine. Once in the large intestine, the molecules transform into their active form. These active forms of laxative lead to cell damage in the lining of the intestine and death by apoptosis and create a dark pigment, lipofuscin, which eventually lines the large bowel. Eventually, these dead cells are taken up by macrophages. Melanosis coli can occur within only a few months of chronic laxative use. 

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analogue- lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

The main indication of laxatives is the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic constipation.

Docusates are associated with side effects like cramps, abdominal pain, and hepatotoxicity on prolonged usage. Liquid paraffin may be associated with foreign body granulomas, lipid pneumonia, and vitamin deficiencies. Bisacodyl may cause allergic reactions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was subjected to cardiac MRI and the left ventricle showed spade-like deformity as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of spade-like deformity of the left ventricle in cardiac MRI points towards a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, also called Yamaguchi syndrome, is characterized by hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations. The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than the traditional septal form of HCM. The ECG shows giant T wave inversions in apical precordial leads.

The given MRI image shows apical hypertrophy & obliteration of the LV apical cavity at end-diastole, with a typical spade-like configuration.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones.

These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation.

The below image shows an ammonium urate stone.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days.

The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearance of clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are:

  • P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days)
  • P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days)
  • P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days)
  • P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days)

Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and the time when they first become detectable in blood.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

questions.text: A patient with pre-eclampsia presents with profuse bleeding after delivery. Which of the following drugs can be used in the medical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
PPH in a patient with pre-eclampsia can be treated with misoprostol. It is a PGE1 analogue used as a second line uterotonic in the treatment of PPH.

The drug of choice for PPH in normal patients is oxytocin.

Option A: Methergine and other ergot derivatives cause dangerous hypertension in pre-eclampsia.

Options B and D: Carboprost and Dinoprost cause severe hypertension in pre-eclampsia.
