questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with an obstetric code of P3L3 came with complaints of heaviness in her pelvic region. The uterine prolapse was similar to the illustration given below. What is the degree of prolapse?
questions.solution:
The given condition is a second-degree uterine prolapse, where the cervix descends to the level of the vulva as seen in the image above. 

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of supports. It is classified based on compartment of descent. 

It has multifactorial etiology. It is thought that combinations of anatomical, physiological, genetic, lifestyle, and reproductive factors are responsible for pelvic floor dysfunction. However, pregnancy, vaginal delivery, prior pelvic surgeries, or conditions associated with sustained episodes of increased intraabdominal pressure increase the risk of developing pelvic organ prolapse. 

Patients may be asymptomatic. Those who have symptoms may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. It may cause bladder outlet obstruction, affect sexual activity, body image, and quality of life. 

The following image depicts the degrees of prolapse:

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of him appearing lethargic and irritable when touched. On examination, his skin is dry, eyes are sunken and hyperreflexia is present. Blood reports show serum sodium to be 150 mEq/L and high serum osmolarity. Which of the following is correct regarding the initial resuscitation of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describing a lethargic child with hyperreflexia, irritability, dry skin, and sunken eyes in the setting of hypernatremia is suggestive of hypernatremic dehydration. The initial resuscitation should include a slow infusion of normal saline rather than ringer lactate.

Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration. Children are often lethargic, and they may be irritable when touched. Hypernatremia may cause fever, hypertonicity, and hyperreflexia. 

Hypernatremia causes the movement of water from brain cells into the hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within the brain. If not treated can lead to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.

The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes the movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death. To minimize the risk of cerebral edema during the correction of hypernatremic dehydration, the serum sodium concentration should not decrease by >10 mEq/L every 24 hr. The deficits in severe hypernatremic dehydration may need to be corrected over 2-4 days.

The initial resuscitation requires the restoration of intravascular volume with normal saline (NS). Ringers lactate should not be used as it is more hypotonic than NS and may result in a very rapid decrease in serum concentrations, especially if multiple fluid boluses are necessary.

(Note: Vice versa for hyponatremic dehydration, if hyponatremic dehydration is treated rapidly with 3% saline, it increases the risk of central pontine myelinolysis)

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: The use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Tracheoesophageal fistula is a contraindication for the use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent. An isotonic, non-ionic iodinated contrast agent can be used instead.

Barium sulfate is not absorbed as it passes through the gastrointestinal tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised (perforation) or when there is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow and leak into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and causing widespread granuloma formation and anaphylactic reactions. 

Contraindications to Barium

  1. Esophageal perforation
  2. Perforation peritonitis
  3. Tracheoesophageal fistula

Iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum.

Note: Although Gastrograffin (water-soluble) was used previously as an alternative to barium contrast, it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema consequently. Hence, it is not preferred nowadays.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to this child?
questions.solution:
2 lakh IU of vitamin A should be administered to a 2-year-old child with vitamin A deficiency.

Dosage of vitamin A in children:

  • 50,000 IU for children less than 6 months of age
  • 1 lakh IU for children between 6 months to 12 months of age
  • 2 lakh IU for children above 12 months of age. 

These doses of vitamin A are to be administered on days 1, 2 and 14 for the treatment of vitamin A deficiency.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: A baby born to an HIV positive mother was brought to the clinic. You suspect the baby to be infected too. Which of the following clinical features may suggest stage 1 HIV in this patient?
questions.solution:
Persistent lymphadenopathy is seen in stage 1 of AIDS in children

Presentations of clinical-stage 1 of AIDS include the following:

  • The child may be asymptomatic.
  • Persistent lymphadenopathy may be observed.

Other options:

  • Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections occur in stage 2
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea and fever occur in stage 3

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: A person has not drunk enough water for the past 2 days and excretes highly concentrated urine. Which of the following is least likely to be involved in creating a hyperosmotic renal medullary interstitium which is responsible for producing the concentrated urine?

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Of the given options, the vasa recta are least likely to be involved in creating a hyperosmolar renal medullary interstitium.

The vasa recta primarily function as countercurrent exchangers in the process of producing concentrated urine. Despite a large amount of fluid and solutes being exchanged across the vasa recta, the net dilution in the concentration of the medullary interstitial fluid is minimal. Thus, the vasa recta do not help create the medullary hyperosmolarity but prevent it from being dissipated.

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration in the renal medulla are 

  • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium. (Option A)
  • Ions are actively transported from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Urea (Option C) moves from the inner medullary collecting ducts (Option B) into the medullary interstitium via facilitated diffusion
  • Only small amounts of water diffuse from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

Related Pearl: Renal tubule characteristics

Segments

Active NaCl Transport

Permeability

H20

NaCl

Urea

Proximal tubule

++

++

+

+

Thin descending limb

0

++

+

+

Thin ascending limb

0

0

+

+

Thick ascending limb

++

0

0

0

Distal tubule

+

+ADH

0

+

Inner medullary collecting duct

KEY: ADH, antidiuretic hormone; NaCl, sodium chloride; 0, minimal level of active transport or permeability; +, moderate level of active transport or permeability; ++, high level of active transport or permeability; +ADH, permeability to water or urea is increased by ADH.

questions.text: What is the angle formed between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the center of rotation of the eyeball?
questions.solution:
Angle gamma is formed between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the centre of rotation of the eyeball.

Axes of the eye:

  • Optic axis – Line passing through the centre of cornea, centre of lens and meets retina on nasal side of fovea.
  • Visual axis – Line passing through fixation point, nodal point and fovea.
  • Fixation axis – Line passing through fixation point and centre of rotation.
  • Pupillary line – Line perpendicular to the cornea at the point coinciding to the centre of pupil.

Angles:

  • Angle alpha: Angle between visual axis and optic axis at the nodal point.

Mnemonic: VOA (Voice Of America) Visual axis, Optic axis and Alpha angle

  • Angle gamma: Angle between Fixation axis and optic axis at the centre of rotation of eyeball. 

Mnemonic: FOG – Fixation axis, Optic axis, Gamma angle

  • Angle kappa: Angle between pupillary line and visual axis at cornea.

Mnemonic: PVK (Pak V/S Kashmir) – Pupillary line, Visual axis, Kappa angle.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy was brought unconscious to the ER. Later it was found out from his brother that he had taken 10-12 sleeping tablets as his girlfriend broke up with him last week. Which section deals with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Attempt to commit suicide was defined under Section 309 of the IPC. 

This provision was, in effect, repealed by Section 115 of the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017. Hence, it was not added to the text of the BNS.  

Abetment of suicide (support or aid to commit suicide) is defined under Section 108 BNS (306 IPC). It states that if any person commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to 10 years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Section

Deals with

BNS 107/ IPC 305

Abetment of suicide of child or person of unsound mind

BNS 108/ IPC 306

Abetment of suicide of a sane individual

BNS 109/ IPC 307

Attempt to murder

BNS 110/ IPC 308

Attempt to commit culpable homicide

IPC 309

(not added to BNS)

Attempt to commit suicide

questions.text: A middle-aged man suffering from chronic constipation presents with swelling in the inguinal region. On further evaluation, the swelling was confirmed to be due to direct inguinal hernia. Identify the following surgical landmark (denoted in green) from where this type of hernia arises.
questions.solution:
The surgical landmark (shown in green) from where a direct inguinal hernia arises is the Hesselbach triangle.

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle:

  • Laterally by inferior epigastric artery 
  • Medially by the lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by inguinal ligament

The floor of the Hesselbach triangle is formed by the transversalis fascia.

A hernia refers to the protrusion of part of the contents of the abdominal cavity through a weakness in the abdominal wall. Inguinal hernias may be direct or indirect. Direct inguinal hernias occur within Hesselbach triangle, while indirect inguinal hernias occur lateral to the triangle.

Patients present with an abdominal lump that is usually painless, but sometimes with an aching or heavy feeling. Cough impulse is usually present, and it is usually reducible. Treatment is urgent in irreducible hernias. Diagnosis is usually clinical.

Other options:

Option A: The boundaries of the triangle of pain are the iliopubic tract, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve are located here.

Option C: The boundaries of the triangle of doom are the vas deferens, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The external iliac artery and vein are found in this triangle.

Option D: Corona mortis is an anastomosis between the obturator and the external iliac or inferior epigastric arteries or veins, which can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage if accidentally cut.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the proteasomal degradation of proteins?

choices.text: Misfolded proteins are degraded in this process.
Ubiquitin is the key molecule involved.

questions.solution:
Option D is the false statement. Proteasomal degradation of proteins is an ATP-dependent process.

The proteasome consists of a macromolecular, cylindrical complex of proteins. It consists of four rings with a hollow core containing the protease active sites, and one or two caps or regulatory particles. The regulatory particles recognize the polyubiquitinated substrates and initiate the degradation of the protein.

Ubiquitin is the key molecule in protein degradation. Degradation of regulatory proteins with short half-lives and of abnormal or misfolded proteins occurs in the cytosol, and this process requires both ATP and ubiquitin.

Bortezomib, carfilzomib, and ixazomib are proteasome inhibitors. They inhibit proteolytic degradation of multiple cellular proteins and are used in the treatment of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Genomic library is a term used to describe ______

choices.text: A computerized listing of known DNA sequences
Bacterial plasmids containing DNA fragments representing the majority of the genetic information from a plant or animal
A library of complementary DNA copies of the population of mRNAs in a tissue
A compilation of the amino acid sequences of protein coding genes

questions.solution:
A genomic library is bacteria with plasmids containing DNA fragments representing the majority of the genetic information from a plant or animal.

Gene library describes the combination of restriction enzymes and various cloning vectors allows the entire genome of an organism to be individually packed into a vector. A collection of these different recombinant clones is called a library.

A genomic library is prepared from the total DNA of a cell line or tissue. A cDNA library comprises complementary DNA copies of the population of mRNAs in a tissue. (option C)

Genomic DNA libraries are often prepared by performing partial digestion of total DNA with a restriction enzyme that cuts DNA frequently.

The International Day for Biological Diversity is a United Nations–sanctioned international day for the promotion of biodiversity issues. It is currently held on May 22.

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Radiological investigations of a patient with a groin hernia revealed a portion of the wall of the hernia sac is formed by the colon along with a defect in the posterior wall.  According to Nyhus classification, what is the type of groin hernia is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above case, as the colon (internal organ) composes a portion of the wall of the hernial sac is suggestive of a sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia. According to Nyhus classification, a posterior wall defect along with sliding hernia is classified as type III.

A sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus is involved in the colon or urinary bladder.

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text: Which of the following points is false about the Albers-Schonberg disease?

choices.text: Ostietis of the mandible is relatively common
Bones appear dense and sclerotic on X-rays
X-ray of vertebrae show rugger-jersey sign
It is caused due to defective osteoblastic activity

questions.solution:
Albers–Schönberg disease is also called as Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease. It is caused due to a defect in the osteoclastic activity. All the other options are true regarding this disease.

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to a mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts). Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anaemia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Osteitis of the mandible is relatively common due to an alteration in the vascularity.

Blood investigations show low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels. Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. Radiolucent bands of sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and are referred to as rugger-jersey sign.

Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida who is in her second trimester of pregnancy is scheduled for an open appendectomy.  What is the preferred anaesthetic technique for this surgery?
questions.solution:
Spinal anesthesia is preferred over other techniques for the appendectomy in the second trimester. Total anesthetic drug exposure is least with spinal anesthesia over others.

General anesthesia is associated with a greater risk of:

  • Pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents
  • Difficult or failed intubation
  • Drug exposure to the fetus

Epidural anesthesia has the risk of:

  • Accidental intravascular injection
  • Accidental intrathecal injection

Although spinal anesthesia is preferred in most situations, the choice between general anesthesia and spinal anesthesia is to be individualized. In general, spinal anesthesia is appropriate for open appendectomies and general anesthesia for laparoscopic appendectomies.

Related Pearl: Regional Anesthesia in Obstetrics

  • Pregnant patients display enhanced sensitivity to LA during regional anesthesia because of hormonal factors and engorgement of epidural venous plexus resulting in decreased epidural space and subarachnoid space (CSF volume).This enhances the cephalad spread of LA solution during spinal and epidural anesthesia.
  • Lower doses of LA agents and pain relief drugs are used because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics during parturition as a result of hormonal and cardiovascular effects.
  • Lignocaine is less protein bound and nerves are more sensitive to LA agents.
  • NOT a cause of decreased anesthetic requirement during pregnancy Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • The level of the block under spinal anesthesia is desirable upto T4.
  • Lumbar epidural - The most preferred technique for painless labor.

questions.text: Rekha brought her 5-day-old infant to the clinic because of feeding difficulties. She says he does not latch properly. Her antenatal history is significant for polyhydramnios and decreased fetal movements. On examination, hypotonia and hyporeflexia are noted in the baby. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only Spinal muscular atrophy presents in infancy. The rest present in late childhood.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a degenerative disease of motor neurons, that is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It usually starts in infancy with hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and thin muscle mass (atrophy). Polyhydramnios may be present prenatally due to weakness in swallowing.

Diagnosis is done by genetic testing for SMN gene mutation. Muscle biopsy is done for cases with negative genetic testing and strong clinical suspicion. The muscle biopsy in infancy shows a characteristic pattern of perinatal denervation that is unlike that of a mature muscle. Groups of giant type I fibers are mixed with fascicles of severely atrophic fibers.

Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.

Recent updates:

  • Nusinersen is an antisense oligonucleotide approved by the FDA for treating SMA. It is administered intrathecally.
  • Risdiplam (first oral drug) has been approved by FDA to treat infants >2 months of age with SMA. It is an oral splicing modifier that corrects the splicing defect of SMN2, which leads to increased levels of full-length SMN protein.

questions.text: An anxious pregnant mother rushed to the emergency department with complaints of decreased fetal movements.  A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted. What does this signify?
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates cord compression.

Decelerations are variable in all respect of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing to the uterine contractions. It is the most common type. Accelerations often precede and follow the deceleration.

Note: Deceleration is a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: The attachment of Eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through ________
questions.solution:
The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. Eukaryotic mRNAs have 7-methylguanosine caps at the 5' end and poly-A tails at the 3' end.

The 7-methylguanosine caps (Guanyl caps) are necessary for:

  • Processing of primary transcripts to mRNA.
  • Mediating the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome for translation.
  • Protection of mRNA against nucleolytic attack by 5'exonucleases.

Other options:

Option A: AAUAAA is present at the 3’ end, which is the polyadenylation sequence (poly-A tail). They help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.

Option B: tRNA molecules serve as adapters for the translation of the information in the sequence of nucleotides of the mRNA into specific amino acids.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

Note: The guanyl cap and poly-A tail aid in attaching the mRNA to the ribosome for translation, however, it is initiated and mediated first through the Guanyl cap.  The poly(A) tail stimulates recruitment of the 40S ribosomal subunit to the mRNA, after which the ribosomal subunit binds to the guanyl cap at 5'end of mRNA.

questions.text: A 22-week pregnant woman presents to the OPD for a routine check-up. On examination, her BP is 150/100 mmHg but she does not have a history of hypertension. You prescribe methyldopa to treat her. On which of the following receptors does this drug act?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a diagnosis of gestational hypertension, for which methyldopa is used. It acts on α2 receptors. 

Methyldopa is a centrally acting α2-adrenergic receptor agonist that is converted into alpha-methyl-norepinephrine. It decreases central sympathetic outflow, decreasing systemic vascular resistance without decreasing cardiac output.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option C: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of desmopressin that is used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus.

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder that occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist of vasopressin. It can be given by iv or sc injection, nasal inhalation, or orally. 

Principal cells in the collecting duct have V2 receptors on their basolateral membrane. When stimulated, they increase the insertion rate of water channels - aquaporin2, into the apical membrane. This increases water permeability. V2 receptors also increase the permeability of urea and help in the renal conservation of water.

Activating endothelial V2 receptors by desmopressin or vasopressin increases circulating levels of procoagulant factor VIII and the von Willebrand factor.

Related Pearl: Types of vasopressin receptors and their functions

Receptor Localization Functions
V1a
  • Vascular smooth muscle
  • Platelets
  • Hepatocytes
  • Myometrium
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Platelet aggregation
  • Glycogenolysis
  • Uterine contraction
V3/V1b 
  • Anterior pituitary
  • ACTH release
V2
  • Basolateral membrane of collecting tubule
  • Vascular endothelium
  • Vascular  smooth muscle
  • Upregulation of Aqp2
  • vwF & factor 8 release
  • Vasodilation

questions.text: Type of glomerulopathy seen in HIV
questions.solution: About 50% of HIV-infected patients with kidney disease have HIV associated nephropathy ( HIVAN) on biopsy. The lesion in HIVAN  is FSGS, characteristically revealing a collapsing glomerulopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Epsilometer (E-test) is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.

E-test is a modification of the agar diffusion susceptibility test. It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) in µg/mL of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  • Diffusion methods: The drug diffuses through a solid medium so that a gradient is established. The concentration is highest near the site of drug application and decreases with distance. The test bacterium is cultured on the medium and its sensitivity to the antibiotic is determined by the zone of growth inhibition. Examples include Kirby–Bauer method and Stokes method.
  • Dilution methods: Serial dilutions of the drug are prepared and inoculated with bacteria. Examples include tube dilution method and agar dilution method
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

questions.text: Which is the most common normal variant of G6PD?
questions.solution:
The most common normal variant of G6PD is G6PD B.

Two variants, designated as G6PD– and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of the clinically significant hemolytic anemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereas that of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced.

G6PD Mediterranean is the most severe variant.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady is in the latent phase of labor for 8 hours. The latent phase would be said to be prolonged in her if it lasts for more than _______________
questions.solution:
The latent phase is said to be prolonged in a multigravida if it lasts for more than 14 hours.

Friedman defined prolonged latent phase by:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase 

The first stage of labor consists of two phases :

1) Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change(upto 5 cm of cervical dilatation)

2) Active phase: Follows the latent phase, is characterized by rapid cervical change (3-6 cm)

questions.text: Which of the following structure  is located most posteriorly in the interpeduncular fossa?
questions.solution:
The mamillary bodies lie more posteriorly than the other structures in the interpeduncular fossa.

The arrangement of the structures from anterior to posterior in the interpeduncular fossa are as follows:

  • The optic chiasma
  • The tuber cinereum
  • The median eminence and the infundibular stalk
  • The mamillary bodies
  • The posterior perforated substance

questions.text: Which of the following test is not used to confirm live birth?
questions.solution:
Gettler's test is not used to confirm live births. It was used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

Tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: the weight of body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: the weight of body = 1:35
  • Fodere’s test – Based on an increase in weight of lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30 – 40g whereas the weight of the respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Breslau’s second life test: It is based on the air entering the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born foetus.

questions.text: A car driver hit his right knee on the dashboard on the sudden application of the brake during a motor vehicle collision. He complains of pain and swelling in the right knee. On examination, there is an excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur on gently pulling the upper end of the tibia. However, the forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur appears normal. What is the structure most likely to be injured?

choices.text: Both anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a direct anterior blow to the knees such as dashboard injury and excessive backward movement in the posterior drawer test is suggestive of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.

The initial symptoms are very similar to an ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) injury like the immediate swelling. On performing the posterior drawer test, there would be excessive backward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. The majority of patients with an isolated PCL injury will return to a high level of function with just appropriate quadriceps rehabilitation, without the need for surgical intervention.

On performing the anterior drawer test, the normal forward gliding movement of the tibia in relation to femoral condyles is suggestive of apparently normal anterior cruciate ligaments. 

Dashboard injury can also lead to

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture of neck of the femur
  • The shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

The image below is an MRI of the knee joint, and the arrow shows the posterior cruciate ligament.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: The operating surgeon while performing thyroidectomy, incidentally found a neoplastic lesion suspicious of papillary carcinoma. What is the ideal size to label it as 'papillary microcarcinoma'?
questions.solution:
The ideal size to diagnose as papillary microcarcinoma is less than 1 cm.

These lesions are most commonly an incidental finding in patients undergoing surgery. They may be a precursor of typical papillary carcinomas. They have no evidence of local invasiveness and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is posted for surgery under general anesthesia. She is on the second day of her menstrual cycle on the day of her surgery. She has a previous history of postoperative emesis and motion sickness. Which of the following should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates that the patient has significant risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Nitrous oxide is avoided in patients at high risk of PONV. 

PONV has an incidence of 20-30% in the general surgical population and 70-80% in those with predisposing risk factors. It is seen within 24 hours of discharge, usually in an ambulatory surgery patient.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient factors 
    • Young age, female gender, particularly if menstruating on the day of surgery or in the first trimester of pregnancy
    • History of prior postoperative emesis
    • History of motion sickness
  • Anesthetic techniques
    • General anesthesia
    • Drugs: Opioids, Volatile agents, Nitrous oxide
  • Surgical procedures
    • Strabismus surgery
    • Ear surgery
    • Laparoscopy
    • Breast surgery
  • Postoperative factors
    • Postoperative pain
    • Hypotension

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

Other options:

Option A: Opioids in themselves have high risk of causing PONV, however when combined with Ketamine there is a very significant reduction in the causation of PONV. Various meta-analysis have proven that when given given together ketamine reduces the opiate effects particularly PONV.

Option B: Propofol when given preoperatively helps reduce the incidence of PONV.The prophylactic administration of propofol as a maintenance anesthetic during breast surgery was found to be more effective in averting postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) than 4 mg of ondansetron.

Option D: Benzodiazepines such as Midazolam are known to reduce PONV. They are given to children to help reduce the incidence of PONV at a dose of 0.05mg/kg.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for the treatment of nocturnal enuresis?
questions.solution:
Clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant used for the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and not for nocturnal enuresis.

In children above 5 years, Imipramine 25 mg at bedtime is effective for nocturnal enuresis. Intranasal desmopressin is also effective in the treatment of nocturnal enuresis.

Bedwetting alarms make a loud tone when they sense moisture. This helps to condition the child to wake at the sensation of a full bladder.

questions.text: What is the name of the valve present between the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac?
questions.solution:
The valve of Rosenmüller is present between the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac. It is a mucosal valve and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi.

Anatomy of the Lacrimal drainage system:

  • The puncta are openings on the lid margin.
  • Each canaliculi (superior and inferior) has two parts: 
    • Vertical (2 mm)
    • Horizontal (8 mm)
  • The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac.
  • The lacrimal sac is 10–12 mm long and lies in the lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.
  • The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner).

 Image: Lacrimal apparatus

questions.text:
Which of the following structures of HBV aid in the survival of HDV?

HBV - Hepatitis B virus
HDV - Hepatitis D virus
questions.solution:
Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an incomplete/defective virus. It requires HBV, to provide the envelope protein (HbsAg) to aid in its survival. Hepatitis D is called the delta virus.

Two types of infection may occur:  

  • Co-infection - acute HDV and HBV infections occur simultaneously
  • Super-infection - Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harboring HBV. This most often leads to chronic hepatitis

Coinfection and superinfection can cause fulminant hepatitis. HBV vaccination is protective against HDV.

questions.text: A man suffered from a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. Gram stain was done and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gas gangrene. The most likely causative organism is Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is a consequence of missile wounds and crush injuries. It is commonly caused by Clostridium perfringens, a spore-forming, gram-positive saprophyte. C. bifermentans, C. septicum, and C. sporogenes are the other organisms causing this condition.

Following crush injuries, the spores gain access to the body. These spores germinate under anaerobic conditions and start producing toxins. The alpha toxin (lecithinase) produced by C. perfringens, destroys red and white blood cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and muscle cells. The kappa toxin destroys connective tissue and blood vessels.

Patients present with severe pain, swelling of the limb, serosanguinous discharge, bluish-black discoloration, soft tissue crepitus, and hemorrhagic bullae. Other signs such as pyrexia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status may be seen. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. A peripheral blood smear can show hemolysis. Gram stain reveals gram-positive bacilli. Radiography is used to visualize gas in soft tissue.

Robertson-cooked meat media is used for the culture of anaerobic organisms like Clostridia. It consists of fat-free minced meat in broth. The organisms may be saccharolytic or proteolytic. The saccharolytic species turns the meat pink, while the proteolytic species turn it black.

Management is by admission to the intensive care unit and administering high-dose penicillin G and clindamycin with intravenous third-generation cephalosporins. Surgical excision to remove the debrided tissue should be done.

The below image shows bluish-black discoloration and hemorrhagic bullae due to gas gangrene.

Related Pearl: Oxygen Requirements of Bacteria

Type of organism

 Feature Examples 
Obligate Aerobes

Always require oxygen for their growth. 

Cannot ferment or respire anaerobically.

M.tuberculosis 

Bacillus sp

Legionella sp

Bordetella sp

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Obligate Anaerobes

 

Can't grow in the presence of oxygen as most of them don’t have Superoxide dismutase and Catalase.

 

Clostridium sp.

Bacteroides sp.
Micro-aerophilic

Require small amounts of oxygen (2–10%) for aerobic respiration. Higher oxygen concentrations are inhibitory.

H. pylori

Campylobacter jejuni 

M.bovis
Facultative anaerobe

Can grow aerobically or anaerobically based on the surrounding environment

Many organisms including Enteric gram-negative bacteria, S. aureus, Vibrio cholerae
Aero-tolerant

Are indifferent to Oxygen. They are basically anaerobic organisms but can tolerate oxygen.

Peptococcus anaerobius

Lactobacillus sp.

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be left in the body after 4 half-lives, If the drug is eliminated by first order kinetics?
questions.solution:
The percentage of drug given that will be left in the body if the drug is eliminated by first-order kinetics after 4 half-lives is 6.25%.

The half-life (T1/2) is the time it takes for the plasma concentration of the drug to be reduced by 50%. In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The half-life of the drug remains constant in first-order kinetics. The rate of clearance is also constant.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who was operated for a femur fracture complains of shortness of breath on the fourth postoperative day. She has chest pain and tachycardia as well. Her chest X-ray is shown below. This finding is most probably suggestive of ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the X-ray showing Hampton's hump is suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest x-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Hampton's hump is a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.
  • Chest x-ray: A large part of the right hemithorax is hypodense due to oligaemia, secondary to vasoconstriction distal to an embolus.
  • Fleishner sign: Enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Knuckle or sausage sign, describing a dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign: Dilated right descending pulmonary artery (Image below):
  • Melting sign: infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.
  • Elevated hemidiaphragm.
  • The best known indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell's sign. That is hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with the normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A boy with a BMI of 16.5 kg/m2 is admitted to the hospital for nutritional rehabilitation for restricting-type anorexia nervosa. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Self-induced vomiting is not a feature of restrictive-type anorexia nervosa. It is seen in the purging type.

Anorexia nervosa has been divided into two clinical subtypes:

Restricting-type Purging-type
Food intake is highly restricted (limited calories) Alternate attempts at rigorous dieting with intermittent binge or purge episodes
Compulsively overactive, with overuse athletic injuries Secondary compensation by self-induced vomiting or laxative abuse
Socially isolated, depressed, and diminished sexual interest Socially isolated, depressed, and diminished sexual interest

questions.text: Which of the following methods is called the ovulation method?
questions.solution:
Billings method or cervical mucus method is called the ovulation method.

It is based on the observation of changes in the cervical mucus. At ovulation, the mucus is watery clear, smooth, and slippery and profuse After ovulation, it becomes thicker and scarce. To use this method, a woman must have high motivation and should know to notice the changes in the cervical mucus.

Other options :

Option B - The symptothermic method employs the combined use of the temperature, cervical mucus and calendar techniques for identifying the fertile period. The use of multiple methods makes it more reliable than using any one method and is hence more effective.

Option C - In Coitus interruptus, no costs or appliances are required and is practised by the withdrawal of the penis right before ejaculation.This prevents the deposition of semen in the vagina. This method of contraception has a high rate of failure (upto 25%) where the major drawbacks are that precoital secretions may contain sperm and that even a drop of semen might be adequate to cause conception. Poorly timed withdrawal might also lead to pregnancy.

Option D - Also known as the "calendar method", the rhythm method is based on calculating the fertile period of the female. The calculations are as follows :

  • First day of fertile peroid : Shortest cycle - 18 days
  • Last day of fertile period : Longest cycle - 10 days

Intercourse is then avoided during this fertile period.

Drawbacks :

  • Irregular menstrual cycles
  • Used only in educated couples who are motivated and cooperative.
  • Abstinence for half a month leading to "programmed sex"
  • Cannot be used in the postnatal period
  • High rate of failure (9 per 100 woman-years)

questions.text: According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex maintains the vaginal length and horizontal axis. It allows the vagina to be supported by the levator plate and positions the cervix just superior to the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.

Level I support suspends the proximal vagina. Level II support attaches the midvagina along its length to the arcus tendineus fascia. Level III support results from the fusion of the distal vagina with adjacent structures. 

Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benzylisoquinoline compound?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium is a steroidal compound. The other options are all benzylisoquinoline compounds.

Classification of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants according to structure:

  • Steroidal compounds:
    • Pancuronium
    • Pipecuronium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Benzylisoquinoline compounds:
    • d - Tubocurarine
    • Metacurine
    • Doxacurium
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Mivacurium
  • Onium chlorofumarate compounds - Gantacurium 
  • Phenolic ethers - Gallamine
  • Diallyl derivative of toxiferine - Alcuronium

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

A grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of middle ear and used in cases where fluid collection recurs.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent UTIs, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous urogram shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole, referred to as the drooping lily sign, observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. As a result, the affected individual may have two collecting systems for one kidney. 

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction or ureterocoele. When the upper pole ureter is obstructed, the lower pole collecting system appears displaced and stretched on imaging, creating the "drooping lily" sign observed in intravenous urography. 

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage. When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction.
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Most common symptom seen in patients with hypothyroidism is?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of hypothyroidism is tiredness and weakness.

Symptoms and signs in decreasing order of frequency are given below:

Symptoms

Signs
  • Tiredness, weakness
  • Dry skin
  • Cold intolerance
  • Hair loss
  • Difficulty concentrating and poor memory
  • Constipation
  • Weight gain with poor appetite
  • Dyspnea
  • Hoarse voice
  • Menorrhagia (later oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea)
  • Paresthesia
  • Impaired hearing
  • Dry coarse skin, cool peripheral extremities
  • Puffy face, hands, and feet (myxedema)
  • Diffuse alopecia
  • Bradycardia
  • Peripheral edema
  • Delayed tendon reflex relaxation
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Serous cavity effusions

questions.text: An epidemic of cholera has broken out and public health workers are taking rigorous measures to control the infection. Which of the following methods is preferred to disinfect small household wells in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The double pot method is preferred for disinfecting small wells as an emergency measure. This is because a constant dose of chlorine is desirable at the time of emergencies like a cholera epidemic.

Using bleaching powder is the most effective and cheapest method of disinfecting wells. The double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it. The inner pot has it in the upper portion and the outer pot it is placed 4 centimeters above the bottom. The hole in the outer pot is covered with polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled up to 3 centimeters below the hole with a mixture of bleaching powder and coarse sand. It is then placed in the outer pot. The double pot system is then lowered into a well and immersed at least 1 meter below the water level. It can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 liters of water.

Other options:

Option A: Horrock's apparatus is used to estimate the dose of bleaching powder needed for the disinfection of water. 

Option C: High-test hypochlorite also known as perchloron has 60-70% of available chlorine. It is more stable than bleaching powder and deteriorates less on storage. It is carried out for household purification of water.

Option D: Multi-stage reverse osmosis method is used for household purification of water. It makes water both chemically and microbiologically potable. It has a clarity cartridge and reverse osmosis cartridge.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a tendency to sunburn easily, and dry, scaly skin.  He has short and brittle hair and sparse eyebrows. Under polarized light microscopy of the hair strand, a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands is seen.  What can be the  DNA repair defect in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trichothiodystrophy (TTD) which is caused by defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). Features like developmental delay, short stature, photosensitivity, and ichthyosis with short, brittle, and sparse hair are suggestive of the diagnosis. 

Trichothiodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the nucleotide excision repair mechanism.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulfur-deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy. Other features include photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay, and short stature.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi.

T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are intracellular parasites. It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man, and the intermediate host (vector) is a reduviid bug or triatomine bugs.

Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wounds on the surface of the skin are contaminated by feces of the bug.

Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stages for the triatomine bug. No multiplication occurs in this stage. Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgu,t which are excreted in feces.

Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania species; hence, they are frequently known as Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, andthe  reticuloendothelial system.

questions.text: To avoid overcrowding, what is the minimum area required per person in a house?
questions.solution:
To avoid overcrowding, the minimum area required per person in a house is 70 - 90 sq. ft.

The accepted standards against overcrowding are as follows.

No of rooms  No of persons
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
5 rooms 10 persons (1 room for every 2 additional persons)

The floor space standards against overcrowding are as follows.

Area No of persons
110 sq. ft. and more 2 persons
90 – 100 sq. ft. 1 ½ persons (Children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit)
70 – 90 sq. ft. 1 person
50 – 70 sq. ft. ½ person

questions.text: Mapleson's circuit includes types A, B, C, D, E, and F.  Which of the following is the correct order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation?
questions.solution:
The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A. 

The performance of the Mapleson circuit is best studied in the expiratory phase of the respiratory cycle. The efficiency of the Mapleson circuit is determined by the inflow rate required to prevent rebreathing of CO2.

The DEF systems are more efficient than the BC systems. To prevent rebreathing, BC systems require a higher rate of fresh gas inflow than DEF systems. This is because of the pop-off valve present near the fresh gas inflow in BC systems. A significant amount of fresh gas gets vented out through this valve at the end of expiration. In DEF systems, fresh gas flow pushes the exhaled alveolar gas away from the patient and thus reduces rebreathing of CO2.

For Mapleson A circuits, in controlled ventilation, significant rebreathing of CO2 occurs. To prevent this, a very high fresh gas inflow (>20 L/min) is required for Mapleson A. The pop-off valve vents out a significant amount of fresh gas during the inspiratory phase. Thus, Mapleson A has the worst efficiency in controlled ventilation.

During spontaneous breathing, Mapleson A has the best efficiency. During spontaneous ventilation, exhaled alveolar gas is vented through the pop-off during expiration. When the patient inspires, fresh gas is mainly taken in. 

The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB.

Remember:

A > DFE > CB : A Dog Can Bite (Usually a spontaneous event)

DFE > BC > A : Dancing Babies can't assist (controlled)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male underwent coronary artery bypass surgery using a saphenous vein graft. Which of the following can cause early failure of this vascular graft?
questions.solution:
Thrombus can cause early failure of this small-diameter vascular grafts.

Neointimal hyperplasia, atherosclerotic plaque, and aneurysm are the causes of late failure of a vascular graft. In these cases, graft failure occurs over months to years after the surgery.

questions.text: Blackwater fever is a side effect associated with the use of  _________
questions.solution:
Blackwater fever is a type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with the use of quinine. It presents with a triad of massive hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria that may lead to anuria, renal failure, and death. Its use is associated with cinchonism which manifests as tinnitus, visual and auditory disturbances, headache, nausea, and vomiting. It has a stimulatory effect on pancreatic beta cells and can cause hypoglycemia.

Quinidine is also associated with blackwater fever.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the mandibular nerve gives rise to the branch, that supply the postganglionic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
The nerve that supply postganglionic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland is the auriculotemporal nerve. It arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: A primigravida presented with labor pains at 38 weeks of gestation. The baby was in breech presentation and a vaginal breech delivery was planned. Identify the following maneuver performed during the delivery.
questions.solution:
The given maneuver is the modified Prague maneuver done for a chin-to-pubis delivery of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Note: If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau maneuver.

Other options:

Wood's corkscrew maneuver is used to manage shoulder dystocia. It involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­screw fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder. 

In the Zavanelli maneuver, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. It is done as a third line of managing shoulder dystocia after failing to deliver the baby vaginally.

Lovset maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: What form of prevention is the prospective screening of COVID infection among the international passengers at the airport?
questions.solution:
The prospective screening is a form of primary prevention. It is done for the benefit of others, who have not gotten the disease. This is done so that the disease is controlled and not spread. 

The prescriptive screening is done for the case detection, and the people are screened for their own benefits of early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. e.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida who is in her first trimester presented to you for abortion for some personal reasons. What is the antibiotic regime of doxycycline that you will follow to prevent post abortal sepsis?

choices.text: 100 mg orally 1 hour before and then 200 mg orally after a surgical evacuation
100 mg orally 1 hour before and then 100 mg orally after a surgical evacuation
200 mg orally 1 hour before and then 200 mg orally after a surgical evacuation
200 mg orally 1 hour before and then 100 mg orally after a surgical evacuation

questions.solution: Doxycycline 100 mg oral 1 hr before and then 200 mg oral after surgical evacuation is the regime recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists for prevention of post abortal sepsis.

questions.text: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in men is homologous to the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions.

Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.
