questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

questions.text: A factory worker went to work after enjoying his weekend. At the end of the day, he was feeling uncomfortable and had tightness over his chest. However, there were no symptoms in the subsequent days of that week. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Monday chest tightness due to byssinosis. 

They present with chest tightness especially on the first day of the workweek, this is termed “Monday chest tightness”. Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust.

The exposed workers may show a significant drop in FEV1 over the course of a Monday work shift. Initially, the symptoms do not recur on subsequent days of the week, but in a subset of workers, chest tightness may recur or persist throughout the workweek. After >10 years of exposure, workers with recurrent symptoms are more likely to have an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function testing.

questions.text: A 62-year-old lady was planned for coronary angiography through the radial route. The cardiologist had multiple unsuccessful attempts with the radial puncture. As a part of evaluating it, a biopsy of the radial artery was done and is shown below. What is the most probable condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The image shows calcification of the walls of the artery seen as the dark purple stained area on H&E staining.

Monckeberg's medial sclerosis or medial calcific sclerosis is a type of arteriosclerosis, characterized by calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic membrane. The calcifications do not encroach on the lumen and are usually not clinically significant. It is usually an incidental finding. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes.

Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening and loss of elasticity of arterial wall. Other patterns of arteriosclerosis:

  • Arteriolosclerosis: It affects small arteries and arterioles, and may cause downstream ischemic injury. It is associated with hypertension and has two anatomic variants:
    • Hyaline
    • Hyperplastic
  • Atherosclerosis: Most frequent and clinically important pattern which poses a risk of causing coronary, cerebral, and peripheral vascular diseases. It is characterized by the presence of atheromas (also called atheromatous or atherosclerotic plaques) that protrude into vessel lumens.

The image given below is a magnified image of medial calcific sclerosis:

questions.text: Which of the following methods will not help you visualize the bacterial cell wall?
questions.solution:
The cell wall of bacteria cannot be seen with simple stains or direct light microscopy.

The bacterial cell wall is present outside the plasma membrane and confers strength and shape to the cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans. The cell wall can be demonstrated by the following methods:

  • Plasmolysis
  • Microdissection
  • Reaction with specific antibodies
  • Mechanical rupture of the cell
  • Differential staining procedures (E.g. Chance's method)
  • Electron microscopy
  • Fluorescence microscopy

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has accidentally hit his head to an iron nail on the wall. Immediately after this, he started rubbing the injured site with his hand, in an attempt to alleviate the severe pain he experiences. Which of the following nerve fiber is responsible for this fast pain?
questions.solution:
As per the scenario given in the question, the boy is immediately able to appreciate the intensity of the pain, and localise the site as well. This is called the fast pain and Aδ fibres are responsible for this.

The fibres that carry pain are the Aδ fibres and C fibres.

  • The Aδ fibres are myelinated and release glutamate when activated. They are responsible for the first pain (also called fast pain), which is a rapid response and mediates the discriminative aspect of pain or the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus.
  • The C fibres are unmyelinated and release both glutamate and substance P, which are responsible for the second pain (also called slow pain). The slow pain is the dull, intense, diffuse, and unpleasant feeling associated with a noxious stimulus.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female came with complaints of diminished vision on the right eye. There is also a history of cataract surgery two months back on the same eye. The given is the FFA image of the right eye. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given patient with history of cataract surgery and FFA image showing cystoid macular edema by its characteristic "flower petal pattern" points towards the diagnosis of Irvine-Gass syndrome.

It is one of the late postoperative complications of cataract surgery. The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer at the fovea. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

questions.text: The postoperative X-ray of a patient who underwent femoral nailing is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this nail?

choices.text: Proximal migration of the nail may lead to bursitis
Based on the concept of three point fixation
The eye of the nail is useful during its removal

questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a K-nail (Kuntscher nail), identified by the absence of interlocking screws. A cloverleaf shape is seen on cross-section. This is designed to give a good rotational stability. 

K-nails have been used for the internal fixation of femur fractures, and fixation relies on the frictional fit between the nail and bone. It is based on the concept of three-point fixation i.e., at proximal and distal ends of the bone and at the isthmus (the narrowest part of the medullary cavity).

The eye at the end of the nail is useful for removing it after the fracture has healed.

Some common complications of K-nailing include:

  • The nail getting stuck
  • Splintering of the cortex while hammering the nail
  • Proximal migration of the nail, leading to bursitis over its protruding end
  • Distal migration of the nail leading to stiffness of the knee
  • Infection.

questions.solution:
M. gordonae is a common contaminant, often seen in tap waters.

It is also called as 'tap water scoto-chromogen'. It rarely causes pulmonary disease.

questions.text: During the dissection of the shoulder joint, the anatomy resident notices a triangular uncovered area on the joint capsule. Which of the following muscles form the border of this anatomical feature of the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
The anatomical feature of the joint capsule described here is the rotator interval. It lies between the superior edge of the subscapularis and the anterior edge of the supraspinatus.

The rotator interval is an area between the superior edge of the subscapularis and the anterior edge of supraspinatus with the coracoid as the medial boundary of the interval.

It is reinforced by the coracohumeral ligament, the superior glenohumeral ligament, and fibres from the supraspinatus tendon laterally.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient undergoes a session of  Electroconvulsive Therapy. It is noticed that the seizures are prolonged i.e greater than 180 secs and there is also increased postictal delirium. Cessation of which of the following drugs prior to ECT would have prevented this?
questions.solution:
Cessation of lithium would have prevented prolonged seizures and increased postictal delirium. Lithium should be withheld before a session of ECT. 

Normally, for ECTs to be considered effective, induced seizures should last for at least 25 seconds. Prolonged seizures (lasting longer than 180 seconds) or status epilepticus can occur in certain situations. Lithium combined with ECT has been shown to cause prolonged seizures and increased postictal delirium. Doses are withheld for 24 hours prior to treatment, allowing for washout.

Prolonged seizures can be terminated with additional doses of barbiturate anesthetics or IV benzodiazepines. Intubation should also be considered in patients who are apneic for extended periods. Seizures lasting more than 30 minutes can cause permanent neuronal damage.

Other medications to be withdrawn before ECT:

  • Benzodiazepines 
  • Clozapine 
  • Buproprion 
  • Theophylline 
  • Reserpine  

Note: Tardive seizure is a rare complication of ECT. These are seizures that occur after the completion of treatment once the patient has regained consciousness. β-lactam antibiotics and ciprofloxacin have been associated with tardive seizures. 

Other options:

Options A and D:Clozapine and bupropion are associated with the development of late-onset seizures.

Option B: Benzodiazepines have anticonvulsant activity.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a polypeptide hormone?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is an example of a polypeptide hormone.

Cortisol is a steroid hormone. Adrenaline and thyroxine are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The barium swallow study of this patient is shown below. What is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma.

Achalasia cardia is a premalignant condition. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common carcinoma that develops after a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. This occurs due to long-standing retained, undigested fermenting food causing mucosal irritation.

Achalasia cardia is a motility disorder primarily due to the destruction of nerves in the lower esophageal sphincter and secondarily due to degeneration of neuromuscular function of the body of the esophagus.

Clinical manifestations include dysphagia initially to liquids and later to solids, regurgitation, and weight loss. Other symptoms such as heartburn, postprandial choking, and halitosis can occur later.

Manometric studies are the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management includes:

  • Surgical esophagomyotomy.
  • Non-surgical measures like sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, or calcium channel blockers.
  • Injection of botulinum toxin
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) 

Other options:

Option A: Gastric stromal tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

Option C: Gastric lymphomas occur in the stomach and they are mainly non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma occurs in the distal third of the esophagus. It can also occur in patients with achalasia cardia but SCC is more common. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: What is the type of joint marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the given image is the first carpometacarpal joint. It is a saddle type of synovial joint.

In a saddle joint, the articular surfaces are reciprocally concavo-convex. All other carpometacarpal joints are plane type.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the liver is regarded as the 'bare area'?
questions.solution:
The part of the liver marked with 'B' is the bare area of the liver.

The bare area of the liver is a triangular area of the liver that is devoid of peritoneal covering. It is formed by the two layers of the coronary ligament. In this bare area, the liver is attached to diaphragm by loose areolar tissue.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pseudohemoptysis. He was informed that the color of the sputum is due to a pigment produced by a microorganism. What is the most probable microorganism discussed here?
questions.solution:
Pseudohemoptysis is most commonly caused by Serratia marcescens.

Serratia marcescens is a pleomorphic coccobacilli. It may grow in sputum after collection. They may mimic hemoptysis (pseudohemoptysis) because they produce a red pigment called prodigiosin.

S. marcescens contaminate intravenous fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions. Therefore, they are one of the important causes of healthcare-associated infections.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient presented with Shoulder pain on inspiration following severe blunt abdominal trauma that he sustained following RTA. This sign is called:
questions.solution:
Shoulder pain on inspiration is called the Danforth sign and this sign is seen in the case of Hemoperitoneum.

Other signs of hemoperitoneum:

  • Cullen sign: Periumbilical bruising.
  • Kehr sign: Left shoulder pain when supine and pressure placed on the left upper abdomen (especially in hemoperitoneum of splenic origin)
  • Grey Turner sign: Local areas of discoloration around umbilicus and flanks (usually hemoperitoneum following acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis)

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of the feeling of impending doom, accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. Which of the following agents has the most rapid onset of action against her condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder. Benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action in panic, with the onset happening often within the first week.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month are classified as panic disorder. Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

Benzodiazepines such as alprazolam and lorazepam have been widely used for panic disorder. They are often used as a first agent while the serotonergic drug is up-titrated to therapeutic levels. Benzodiazepines are preferred for short-term therapy as long-term use can often lead to dependence and abuse.

Clinically, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and clomipramine are preferred over benzodiazepines, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), and tricyclic and tetracyclic drugs in terms of effectiveness, long-term therapy, and tolerance of adverse effects. 

Related Pearl: Panic disorder

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

1.Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:

  • Palpitation
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Shortness of breath of smothering sensation
  • Choking sensation
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Chills or heat sensation
  • Paraesthesia’s
  • Derealisation or depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control or “going crazy”
  • Fear of dying  

 2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

  • Immediate: benzodiazepines 
  • Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

questions.text: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated with?

choices.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome.

Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:

  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC
    • Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC
  • Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC

The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.

questions.text: A skin transplant was done from a sister to her brother. After a few years, a brother-to-sister skin transplant was done, but rejection occurred. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes an Eichwald-Silmser effect, which is a unilateral sex-linked histo-incompatibility.

While transplants between same-sex siblings are successful, grafts from female to male are also successful, but an exception is seen when the donor is a male and the recipient is a female. Such grafts are rejected as the grafted male tissue (XY) will have antigens determined by the Y chromosome which will be absent in the female (XX) recipient.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle?

choices.text: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
Cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction

questions.solution:
Increased cytosolic Ca2+ is essential for contraction of smooth muscles.

Events in Excitation Contraction Coupling in Smooth Muscles.

A unitary smooth muscle is unique in that it can contract when stretched even in the absence of any extrinsic innervation. Stretch is followed by a decrease in membrane potential and an increase in the tone of the muscle.

 

Other options:

Option a: Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.

Option b: Sustained contraction of the smooth muscle occurs even when the calcium concentration falls. This is mainly because of the latch-bridge mechanism where the myosin cross-bridges remain attached to the actin. This mechanism allows for maintaining the contraction with less expenditure of energy and is particularly important in the vascular smooth muscle.

Option c: Unlike skeletal muscle where troponin binding is essential for contraction, the smooth muscle contraction requires phosphorylation of myosin (not actin).

questions.text: A menopausal woman presents with complaints of hot flushes. Which of the following neurotransmitters are responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women.

A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature.

Risk factors for hot flushes:

  • Low estradiol levels
  • High BMI
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Surgical menopause has increased risk
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
  • Depression.

questions.text: A person experiences heat in her left hand on touching a hot vessel on the stove. In the pathway that carries this sensation of temperature to the brain, the axons of which order neurons cross to the right side?
questions.solution:
In the pathway that carries temperature from the site of sensation to the brain, the axons of second-order neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord.

The pathway that is responsible for conveying the sensations of pain and temperature is the lateral spinothalamic tract. The following are the order of neurons in this tract.

  • First-order neurons - Neurons in the dorsal root ganglia. 
    • These neurons synapse with the neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
  • Second-order neurons - Neurons in the gray matter of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
    • The axons of these neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord at the same level at which the sensation is perceived. They ascend up and synapse with the neurons in the thalamus
  • Third-order neurons - Neurons in the thalamus.
    • Their axons then relay in the postcentral gyrus of the cerebral cortex

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of progressive lower abdominal pain associated with frequent and painful urination. Under antibiotic coverage, cystoscopic examination shows soft, yellow, and raised mucosal plaques. The biopsy study from one of the lesions is given below. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition is described in the given case scenario is Malakoplakia. Escherichia coli is the most common organism involved in this condition.

Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and the central nervous system. Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.   Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy. Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products. In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.

 The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the given bone pathology except:
questions.solution:
The given condition is osteoclastoma/giant-cell tumor (GCT). The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL.

The given image shows an abundance of multinucleated giant cells with a background of mononuclear stromal cells. GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL, which promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue. Sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

Remember E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: Which of the following skull fracture is called the signature fracture?
questions.solution:
Depressed fracture is called the signature fracture.

It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. The fracture shape indicates the type of weapon which produced it. So it is also called signature fracture/ fracture ala signature/ Bone impression fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady who underwent chemotherapy for breast carcinoma 3 weeks ago now presents with diffuse hair loss as shown below. On examination, she has a depressed affect. Name the condition causing her hair loss.
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy causes hair loss known as anagen effluvium.

It is due to the disruption of the anagen or proliferating phase of the hair cycle. Hair shedding typically occurs within 1–3 weeks and it is complete within 1–2 months after the initiation of chemotherapy.

Most important drugs implicated in the order of decreasing frequency of association causing anagen effluvium:

  • Anti-microtubule agents (e.g., paclitaxel)
  • Topo-isomerase inhibitors (e.g., doxorubicin)
  • Alkylating agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide)
  • Anti-metabolites (e.g., 5-fluorouracil)

Option A: Alopecia areata causes patchy, well-circumscribed hair loss, as shown below.

Option B: Telogen effluvium is an acute-onset diffuse hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation or haemorrhage.

Option D: Trichotillomania is a behavioural disorder characterised by compulsive hair pulling which causes patchy hair loss. It shares some features with obsessive-compulsive disorder and may be associated with other psychiatric conditions.

questions.text: In fixed rabies virus infection, Negri bodies are found in?
questions.solution:
In fixed rabies virus infection, Negri bodies are not formed.

Fixed virus of rabies:

Serial brain-to-brain passage of street strain of rabies virus into the rabbit, modifies the virus by reducing the incubation period of the virus to between 4-6 days which stage it is called a fixed virus.

Features of fixed virus:

  • Short, fixed and reproducible incubation period
  • Does not multiply in extraneural tissues
  • Used in the preparation of anti-rabies vaccine

The incubation period of the virus extracted from natural cases (street virus) is 20–60 days in dogs.

The source of infection is the saliva of an infected animal.

questions.text: In eukaryotes, which of the DNA polymerase is involved in mitochondrial DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
DNA Polymerase gamma is involved in mitochondrial DNA Synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the dental numbering system.
questions.solution:
The given dental numbering system is Palmer’s notation

It is used for charting of teeth. Teeth will be numbered from 1 to 8 starting from central incisor till the third molar in each quadrant.

Dental charting:

4 most commonly used methods are:

Universal system (option C): Teeth are numbered 1 – 16 starting from upper right to upper left and 17 – 32 starting from lower left to lower right.

Haderup system (option A): This is similar to Palmer's notation but plus sign (+) indicates upper teeth and minus sign (-) indicates lower teeth.

FDI (Federation Dentaire Internationale):

Number is assigned to each quadrant and that number is placed before tooth's number.

Modified FDI (option D):

questions.text: Which of the following is the embryological origin for the footplate of stapes?
questions.solution:
The footplate of stapes and the annular ligament develops from the otic capsule whereas the stapes suprastructure develops from the second arch.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with dyspnea on the tenth day after giving birth. After a normal routine examination, a transthoracic echocardiogram was done. It showed an LV ejection fraction of 35%. However, there was no significant history in the past. Which of the following drugs has shown to be effective for this type of cardiac condition associated with pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The given condition is peripartum cardiomyopathy and bromocriptine is an effective treatment option.

One of the theories suggests that oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin.

  • The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes.
  • Based on this proposed mechanism, bromocriptine therapy has been suggested because it inhibits prolactin secretion.

Pearson's criteria to diagnose peripartum cardiomyopathy:

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by classic echocardiographic criteria, such as depressed ejection fraction or fractional shortening along with a dilated left ventricle.

questions.text: The X-ray pelvis of a 44-year-old man with intermittent haematuria for the past 3 years is shown below. This condition predisposes to _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows calcification of the bladder wall which is seen in schistosomiasis. Bladder schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia of the bladder, predisposes individuals to squamous cell carcinoma.

Imaging findings in schistosomiasis are suggestive of the pathologic course. In the acute phase, nodular bladder wall thickening is seen at urography or cross-sectional imaging. The characteristic finding in the chronic phase is a contracted, fibrotic, thick-walled bladder with calcifications. The calcifications are usually curvilinear and these represent the large numbers of calcified eggs in the bladder wall. A mass may be secondary to inflammation or complicating carcinoma, typically SCC.

questions.text: A baby born via cesarean section develops a scalp swelling 12 hours after birth, the swelling does not cross the midline. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario in the given question is suggestive of Cephalohematoma. 

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage, which appears several hours after birth and it is always limited to the surface of one cranial bone and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to you with sleep deprivation, elation, and talkativeness for the last 4 days, but his social and occupational functioning is intact. He also complains of irritability and distractibility and gives a history of three episodes of major depression in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of decreased sleep, irritability, distractibility, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days with intact social and occupational functioning suggest an episode of hypomania. Since the patient has had episodes of major depression in the past, the diagnosis is bipolar disorder II.

Types of Bipolar disorder:

  • Bipolar I: Episodes of mania with or without episodes of major depressive disorder. At least one-lifetime episode of mania is required for diagnosis. 
  • Bipolar II: Episodes of hypomania with episodes of major depressive disorder. Major depressive episodes lasting at least 2 weeks and hypomanic episodes lasting for at least 4 days are required for diagnosis. A negative history of a manic episodes is needed for making a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder.

Mania presents with features similar to hypomania but for a duration of at least one week. There is a marked impairment in social and occupational functioning.

The age of onset for bipolar type I disorder ranges from, children of ages 5-6 years to adults aged 50 or above. The mean age of onset is 30 years. The lifetime prevalence of bipolar type 1 disorder is 0 to 2.4%, whereas bipolar type 2 disorder is 0.3-4.8%. Bipolar type 1 disorder is seen with an equal prevalence among men and women. Suicide attempt is seen in approximately 15% of patients affected by bipolar disorder. 

Lithium is used in the pharmacological management of bipolar disorder. Along with it, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines are also used.

Other options:

Option B: Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day.

Option C: Euphoria is an emotional condition marked by intense feelings of well-being, elation, happiness, and joy.

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

Related Pearl: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania Hypomania
Symptoms for at least 1 week Symptoms for at least 4 days
Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning No impairment in social or occupational functioning
May need hospitalization Doesn't need hospitalization

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use

  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
Read the pedigree chart and identify the disorder which follows this pattern.

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

MELAS- mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G-6-PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

Other options:

Option A: Gaucher's disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that arises due to the deficiency of β-glucosidase. It is characterized by hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option B: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This leads to the accumulation of galactose and subsequent tissue damage.

The following image depicts autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Option D: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing an abdominal incision uses the surgical blade that is shown in the figure. What is the size of this surgical blade?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is 22. It is often used for abdominal incisions.

The number 10 is used for skin incisions.

The number 11 is often used for drain insertion and arteriotomy. These blades have a sharp tip. 

The number 15 is often used for minor surgical procedures.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?

ABG - metabolic acidosis

Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL

Blood Urea – 100 mg/dl

Creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl

Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals.
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage. 

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomipezole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient has FBS of 200 mg/dl, PPBS of 432 mg/dl, and HbA1c of 10%. A diabetologist decides to add long-acting insulin into the usual insulin regimen of this patient. Identify the long-acting insulin among the following.

FBS- Fasting blood sugar

PPBS- Post-prandial blood sugar
questions.solution:
Insulin NPH is a long-acting insulin.

Insulin preparations and duration of action:

  • Short-acting
    • Insulin lispro, Insulin aspart, Insulin glulisine: 3-4 hours
    • Regular insulin: 4-6 hours
  • Long-acting
    • Insulin NPH: 10-16 hours
    • Insulin Detemir: 12-24 hours
    • Insulin Glargine: 12-24 hours
    • Insulin Degludec: 24-42 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is the longest part of the large intestine?
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the longest part of the large intestine, measuring 50 cm in length on an average. It is intraperitoneal in location and suspended by the transverse mesocolon.

Lengths of various parts of the large intestine are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder.

VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF).

VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation.

Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 1 disease. 

Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing the natural history of disease, the duration between points A to B is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drug belongs to the class of nitrogen mustards?
questions.solution:
Ifosfamide is a nitrogen mustard. 

 Nitrogen mustards are:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Ifosfamide
  • Mechlorethamine
  • Melphalan
  • Chlorambucil
  • Bendamustine

Nitrosoureas are:

  • Carmustine
  • Lomustine
  • Semustine
  • Streptozocin

Nitrosoureas cause interstrand DNA cross-linking which responsible for the cytotoxicity of the tumor. The use of nitrosoureas is presently limited to brain tumors due to their lipophilicity.

Platinum compounds are:

  • Cisplatin
  • Carboplatin
  • Oxaliplatin

questions.text: Which of the following neurodegenerative disease has superoxide dismutase 1 inclusions?
questions.solution:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD1) inclusions.

It is a form of motor neuron disease that includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology. It is a progressive disease occurring due to the accumulation of mutated SOD1 proteins causing increased free radicals followed by cellular injury of neurons and apoptosis. The disease is characterized by asymmetrical weakness and spasticity of arms and legs. 

The diseases and their associated inclusion bodies are given below:

Disease Inclusion bodies
Huntington's disease Huntington (Polyglutamine)
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis SOD1
Spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy Androgen receptor (Polyglutamine containing)
Multiple system atrophy

α-synuclein
Progressive supranuclear palsy

Tau
Frontotemporal lobar degeneration

Tau, TDP-43

questions.text: A 5- year-old girl has developed a rash over the last few days which is at the corner of her mouth.  On examination, the rash appears as shown below. She is otherwise well, doesn’t complain of pain, and has no history of any other skin disorders. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the image showing honey-crusted/ golden-crusted /yellowish-brown crusted lesions are characteristic of impetigo.

Impetigo is a contagious, superficial bacterial skin infection caused by either Staphylococcus Aureus or Streptococcus Pyogenes. It can be bullous or non-bullous impetigo. It is very common in children, and in particular during summer. It spreads by direct contact with discharges from the scab of an infected person.

If it is mild, management includes removing crusts, washing skin using disinfectants. Topical antibiotics should be applied twice a day for a week.

If it has extensive skin involvement, bullous disease, or lymphadenopathy, treatment should include systemic antibiotics like flucloxacillin along with localized skin treatment.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria?
questions.solution:
The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria in a locality.

It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films. The transmission of malaria is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in a locality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission may remain).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was started on hormone replacement therapy. The patient is a bit worried about the risk of endometrial cancer. What is the minimum duration of progesterone to be added in a month to reduce the risk?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone added to ERT reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%.

Hormone replacement therapy and Endometrial carcinoma:

  • Estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) can cause well-differentiated carcinoma.
  • Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer.
  • Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Raloxifene, unlike tamoxifen, exerts anti-oestrogenic action on the endometrium.
  • The risk of cancer with ERT is dose and duration dependent.

questions.text: The post mortem staining in a patient with suspected poisoning shows bright red color. Which of the following types of hypoxia would have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The bright red post mortem staining is seen in cyanide toxicity. It is associated with histotoxic hypoxia. 

Histotoxic hypoxia in cyanide toxicity is due to its inhibition of complex IV of ETC (cytochrome oxidase a3). 

Toxins that inhibit complex IV of electron transport chain include:

  • Cyanide
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Hydrogen sulfide.

questions.text: An actress wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. However, she is concerned about the resulting scars on her abdomen. Which of the following methods of sterilization would best suit her case?
questions.solution:
Essure would best suit the actress as it is done through the hysteroscopic method, thus, avoiding abdominal scar.

The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). In the inner coil, there is a layer of polyethylene terephthalate fibers that occludes the fallopian tube by initiating a benign local fibrous tissue growth. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. Tubal blockage can be confirmed 3 months later by hysterosalpingography. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and that it can be done under local anesthesia.

However, disadvantages include:

  • Hysteroscopy is required to insert the Essure device
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage after 3 months
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube 
  • The failure rate is 3.5%

Other options

Option A: Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.

Option B:  In Madlener's procedure a loop of the tube is crushed and ligated with a non-absorbable suture.

Option D: In the Pomeroy procedure the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A known patient of Meniere’s disease experienced a sudden drop attack without loss of consciousness. There is no vertigo or fluctuations in the hearing loss. What is the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

It occurs in patients with Meniere’s disease where the patient develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. It is due to the change in the endolymphatic pressure leading to the deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule.

Tullio phenomenon - It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Lermoyez syndrome - Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Vestibular Hydrops - The patient gets typical attacks of episodic vertigo while cochlear functions remain normal.

questions.text: When mercaptoethanol acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following end products are obtained?
questions.solution:
When mercaptoethanol acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, it cleaves the disulphide bonds resulting in 2 Heavy and 2 Light chains.

Enzymatic digestion of antibody with Papain, Pepsin and Mercaptoethanol produces fragments as follows: 

  • Papain: 2 Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
  • Pepsin: One F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known hypertensive presented with pain and swelling in his great toe. The aspirated synovial contents visualized under polarized light microscopy showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. What is the antihypertensive that is preferred in such patients?
questions.solution:
Losartan is the preferred antihypertensive in patients having gout, because of its uricosuric action.

Losartan inhibits active sites for reabsorption and secretion in the proximal renal tubule, hence the net reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubule is decreased. Similarly, calcium channel blockers like amlodipine and diltiazem are found to lower the risk of gout.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of gout flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory hypoxic conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light. WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors(eg. allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (e.g. probenecid) can be used.

Other options-

Options A and D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors like captopril are associated with an increased risk of incident gout among patients with hypertension. β blockers such as propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, and alprenolol, also have been shown to increase serum uric acid levels. 

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text: Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of __________
questions.solution:
Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of 1:5. Sulfamethoxazole is an intermediate-acting sulfonamide with a plasma half-life of around 10 hours. Trimethoprim also has a similar plasma half-life and therefore combined with sulfamethoxazole.

Due to a difference in pharmacokinetic (absorption in GIT) properties of the two drugs, this cannot be achieved by administering them at a dose having the same ratio. Therefore, it is administered at a dose ratio of 1:5 (trimethoprim: sulfamethoxazole) which leads to a plasma ratio of 1:20.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented with multiple slow-growing nodules on the scalp.  A biopsy was taken and the histopathological examination revealed a jigsaw puzzle architecture as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with multiple slow-growing nodules in the scalp and with a 'jigsaw puzzle' appearance on histopathology points toward the diagnosis of cylindromas.

Cylindroma is an appendage tumour with ductal (apocrine or eccrine) differentiation inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to mutation of the CYLD gene. 

Patients present with multiple smooth, firm, pink to red coloured nodules on the forehead and scalp which may or may not be pedunculated. Nodules can coalesce and produce a hatlike growth which gives the name, turban tumour.

Histopathology shows lobules of epithelial cells arranged in a jigsaw or mosaic pattern. Each lobule is composed of islands of basaloid cells in the periphery and a paler zone of cells in the centre.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.

Other options:

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive skin malignancy occurring in sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals. Histology shows peripheral palisading of tumour cells which resemble normal cells of the basal cell layer of the epidermis.

Spiradenoma is a benign tumour of the sweat gland presenting as a solitary, painful bluish dermal nodule. Histology shows lobules containing larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery, with intervening cystic spaces and vascular channels.

Merkel cell carcinoma is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumour of the skin which presents as a smooth reddish round tumour. Histology shows cell nests and trabecular patterns and is often referred to as trabecular carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency ward rolls around on the bed in a futile attempt to find a position free from pain. This attitude of the patient is most likely to be because of
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is most likely to be due to renal colic. A patient of renal colic would have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain and tries to find a pain free position.

On the contrary, a patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and also has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain in peritonitis.

A patient of acute pancreatitis usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain. A patient of meningitis would have neck stiffness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who underwent surgery for appendicitis was given a high dose of opioids postoperatively to relieve the pain. But within a few hours,  a fall in SpO2 and respiratory rate were noted. Which of the following drugs has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid-induced respiratory depression and naloxone has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action on µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centers. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with other CNS depressant substances like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative-hypnotics.

However, droperidol, scopolamine, and clonidine do not increase the respiratory depressant effects of fentanyl or other opioids.

Synthetic:

  • Morphinan series (e.g., levorphanol, butorphanol)
  • Diphenylpropylamine series (e.g., methadone)
  • Benzomorphan series (e.g., pentazocine)
  • Phenylpiperidine series (e.g., meperidine, fentanyl, sufentanil, alfentanil, remifentanil)

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV is the Western blot. 

Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/ 160. 

Other options:

Option A: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is the most commonly used screening test for HIV. It is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test for HIV.

Option C: DNA PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) is a specific test for the detection of HIV infection where proviral DNA from the peripheral lymphocytes of the patient's samples is amplified and identified. When performed correctly, this test has a high specificity and sensitivity.

Option D: p24 which is the core antigen of the virus is the earliest to occur and is employed for early diagnosis. A p24 antigen capture assay where anti-p24 antibodies bound with p24 is used with ELISA to demonstrate HIV. This test is useful in the following scenarios - 

  • Newly exposed to the risk of infection
  • People who test negative for the antibody
  • The terminal phase of infection

questions.text: Berkesonian bias is a type of  _______
questions.solution:
Berkesonian bias is a type of selection bias.

It is due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different diseases, termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatrician. On examination, the child's skull feels soft and appears as shown below. He is also noted to have delayed dentition and bow legs. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
The given findings such as craniotabes (soft skull), frontal bossing, bow legs, and delayed dentition in a child are suggestive of rickets.

Clinical Features of Rickets:

General:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Listlessness
  • Protruding abdomen
  • Muscle weakness (especially proximal)
  • Fractures

Head:

  • Craniotabes: softening of the cranial bones detected by applying pressure at the occiput or over the parietal bones
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed fontanelle closure
  • Delayed dentition
  • Craniosynostosis

Chest:

  • Rachitic rosary: widening of the costochondral junctions which feels like the beads of a rosary
  • Harrison groove: horizontal depression along the lower anterior chest due to pulling of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during inspiration
  • Predisposition to respiratory infections and atelectasis as softening of the ribs impairs air movement

Back:

  • Scoliosis, kyphosis, lordosis

Extremities:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles due to growth plate widening
  • Valgus or varus deformities
  • Windswept deformity: occurs when one leg is in extreme valgus and the other is in extreme varus
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia
  • Coxa vara

questions.text:
An HIV-positive female patient presents with fever and dry cough for 4 weeks. Her chest X-ray is given below and her CD4+ T cell count is 150 cells/ microliter. A lung biopsy was done that showed foamy alveolar infiltrates and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates on H & E staining. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?

H & E - hematoxylin and eosin
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, chest x-ray findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrate and H & E staining findings are suggestive of pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and co-trimoxazole is the drug of choice for treatment as well as prophylaxis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that is found in patients having a CD4+ T cell count <200/µL.

The clinical picture is non-specific with complaints of indolent course of fever, cough, pleuritic pain, and unexplained weight loss. Lab and radiographic findings are also non-specific and show an increase in lactate dehydrogenase levels and symmetric, perihilar, and diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates, respectively. 

Hematoxylin and eosin staining of lung tissue showing foamy alveolar infiltrates and a mononuclear interstitial infiltrate is pathognomonic for P. jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). Demonstration of the organism in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is 100% specific and sensitive for PCP in patients with HIV. 

 

Methenamine silver stain showing black-colored cyst wall of Pneumocystis jirovecii

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as co-trimoxazole) is the treatment of choice for PCP, and it is administered for 21 days, followed by a course for secondary prophylaxis. Concomitantly, glucocorticoids should also be administered to reduce pulmonary inflammation.

Patients who are susceptible to PCP are also given co-trimoxazole as prophylaxis. For patients who are unable to tolerate co-trimoxazole, IV pentamidine is the drug of choice.

Prophylaxis is indicated for other opportunistic infections like Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, if CD4 counts fall below 50 cells/µL; Coccidioides, if CD count is <250/µL; and Cryptococcus, when the CD count is <100/µL.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given X-ray image is the renal pelvis. It is embryologically derived from intermediate mesoderm.

The urinary and reproductive organs are developed from the intermediate mesoderm. 

After the notochord is formed, the intraembryonic mesoderm on either side can be seen organized into 3 layers:

  • Paraxial mesoderm: A thickened plate of the mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites.
  • Intermediate mesoderm: Longitudinal strip of mesoderm that connects paraxial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.
  • Lateral plate mesoderm: A thinner layer of mesoderm that lies laterally. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic coelom that gives rise to pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

questions.text: An intern, on recording BP, noted a 15mm Hg drop in the systolic pressure during the inspiration of the patient. Which of the following conditions will not show this observed phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given phenomenon is the Pulsus paradoxus. It is not seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Obstructive lung disease
  • Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: Which of the following is called the danger area of the nose?
questions.solution:
The olfactory area is called the danger area of the nose. 

Because the olfactory nerve fibers from this area pass through the cribriform plate of ethmoid and can lead to the spread of infection to intracranial space. The trauma of olfactory rootlets can also lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

The olfactory area is bounded laterally by superior turbinate, medially by the corresponding part of the septum, and above by cribriform plate of the ethmoid. It is lined by olfactory epithelium.

questions.text: What is the time taken for the complete regeneration of the placental site?
questions.solution:
The complete regeneration of the placental site takes place in about 6 weeks.

Immediately after delivery, the placental site is approximately palm-sized. Within hours of delivery, it normally contains many thrombosed vessels that ultimately undergo an organization. By the end of the second week, it is 3 to 4 cm in diameter. Placental site involution is an exfoliation process, which is prompted in great part by undermining of the implantation site by new endometrial proliferation.

Thus, involution is not simply absorption in situ. Exfoliation consists of both extension and "down growth" of endometrium from the margins of the placental site, as well as the development of endometrial tissue from the glands and stroma left deep in the decidua basalis after placental separation.

questions.text: A very tall patient presented to surgery OPD with thyroid swelling. On physical examination, long, slender fingers and toes were noted. A neuroma was present in the buccal mucosa. Laboratory reports reveal elevated calcitonin levels with increased urinary catecholamine excretion. The gene mutation responsible for this syndrome is located on ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

MEN 2B comprises

  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC; thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin),
  • Pheochromocytoma (increased excretion of urinary catecholamines),
  • Oral mucosal neuromas,
  • Marfanoid habitus (a very tall patient who has long, slender fingers and toes suggests marfanoid habitus).

Note:

  • MEN 1 is caused by a germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin protein), a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 11.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: Growth Factor Receptors and Associated Tumors

Growth factor receptors and Associated Tumors

Category

ERBB2 (HER)
