questions.text: Identify the condition seen in this X-ray.
questions.solution:
This X ray shows a typical finding of multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract which is indicative of Pneumatosis intestinalis.

It is an uncommon condition where cysts may be located in the subserosa, submucosa, and, rarely, muscularis layer and vary in size from microscopic to several centimeters in diameter.

Pneumatosis not associated with other lesions is referred to as primary pneumatosis.

questions.text: An elder sibling is playing with his 3-year-old sister and he pulls up the child by holding hands. The child starts crying, does not use her arm, and does not let anybody touch it. She presents to the orthopaedics unit with the limb in the position as shown in the image. No swelling or focal point tenderness is elicited but she cries when supination is attempted. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The history of lifting the child by the forearm and later the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow. The subluxation of the radial head is the possible cause in this case.

Pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow is the radial head subluxation from the annular ligament seen more commonly in children less than 6 years of age. 

The underlying mechanism in this deformity is the subluxation of the radial head under the annular ligament and not the olecranon process (option B). This is due to the longitudinal traction applied on an extended and supinated forearm. The clinical features include severe pain and the inability to use the affected arm. Characteristically the child holds the elbow in extension or slight flexion with the forearm pronated as shown in the image above.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of the mechanism of development of a pulled elbow:

 

The diagnosis is usually clinical but a radiograph is obtained to exclude a fracture.

It can be treated by the closed reduction technique of forearm flexion with supination. Immobilization using a sling can be used for symptomatic relief.

Other options:

Option B: Subluxation of the olecranon process is seen in posterior dislocation of the elbow. It often occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand. Examination of the elbow joint may show swelling, deformity, or bruising. Posterior elbow dislocations often present with an upper extremity that is flexed and appears shortened. Initial workup involves X-ray in anteroposterior and lateral view. CT scan is considered when the injury is complex. Simple cases are usually treated with closed reductions.

Option C- Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most common fracture in children. It results from a fall on an outstretched hand. The fracture lies just above the condyles of the humerus with angulation or displacement of the distal fragment. The clinical features include pain and a swollen elbow. An X-ray of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus is given below.

 

Option D- Avulsion of the olecranon process results from the eccentric contraction of the triceps tendon.

Below is the radiograph showing olecranon process avulsion.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Injury around the elbow

     

Mechanism of injury

               Injury
Valgus injury
  • Fracture head and neck of the radius
  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus
  • Ulnar collateral ligament injury
Varus injury
  • Fracture of lateral epicondyle of humerus
  • Radial collateral ligament injury
Hyperextension injury
  • Supracondylar fracture humerus
Axial force

  • Dislocation of the elbow
Fall on the point of the elbow

questions.text: A 55-year-old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Which of the following tools can be used to compare the bone mineral density of this patient to the young normal reference level?
questions.solution:
The given case suggests osteoporosis and T-score are used to compare the bone mineral density of this patient to the young normal reference level.

The above image depicts the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like the pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in the proximal femur area.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: What is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy. Mitral stenosis is the commonest acquired heart lesion during pregnancy.

Condition in pregnancy

Most common lesion

Congenital heart disease

Atrial septal defect

Congenital valvular lesion

Mitral valve prolapse

Cyanotic Congenital Heart disease

Tetrology of Fallot

Acquired valvular heart disease

Mitral stenosis > Mitral regurgitation > Aortic stenosis

questions.text: Stemmer’s sign is due to?
questions.solution:
Stemmer’s sign is seen in grade II lymphedema (Brunner’s grading) and is due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

In case of lymphedema the contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the submalleolar depressions, a ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, the toes appear ‘square’ because of confinement of footwear and the skin on the dorsum of the toes (especially second toe) cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis which is called Stemmer’s sign.

questions.text: While monitoring the saturation of a patient using a pulse oximeter, an intern records readings of SpO2 between 80% to 85% even with a flow of 100% oxygen. Which of the following conditions will lead to these pulse oximetry readings irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2)?
questions.solution:
In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the pulse oximetry reading will be 80% to 85% irrespective of arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2). 

Carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin absorb light at one or both of the wavelengths used by the pulse oximeter. Therefore, the presence of these Hb species in the blood leads to errors in SpO2 readings. In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the SpO2 will be 80% to 85%, irrespective of the SaO2, and a patient with carbon monoxide poisoning will have a falsely elevated SpO2 level.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin. The pulse oximeter probe consists of a light emitter and a photodetector. Transmission pulse oximetry involves placing the emitter and detector on opposite sides of the tissue that is being measured, which is usually the finger.

Potential reasons for artifacts in measurement with a pulse oximeter are given in the table below:

Falsely increased O2 saturation value

  • Carboxy-hemoglobinemia
  • Intra-aortic balloon pump
  • Severe hyper-bilirubinemia

Falsely decreased O2 saturation value

  • Anemia
  • Hypotension (blood pressure- BP<80 mm Hg)
  • Application of nail paint and henna
  • Venous pulsations 

SpO2 estimates the SaO2 of circulating hemoglobin but does not provide information about tissue oxygenation, ventilation, or acid-base status.

Conditions that show inaccuracies in pulse oximeter readings include:

  • Variant hemoglobin species- carboxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin
  • Motion artifacts - SpO2 is decreased compared to SaO2.
  • Venous pulsation
  • The presence of intravascular dyes- methylene blue decreases SpO2 to 65%
  • Presence of nail polish- black, purple, and dark blue show lower SpO2.

questions.text: A patient presents with cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. These are manifestations of which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis are manifestations of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes

  • Succinate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Xanthine oxidase
  • Acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a fetus born dead at 6 months. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Adipocere formation cannot be an autopsy finding in the given scenario since fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

Adipocere is the formation of a soft greyish-white, waxy, greasy material with an offensive, sweet rancid smell, occurring in fatty tissues. It is due to postmortem hydrolysis or hydrogenation of the fats. It is a modification of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in a damp, warm environment. Fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

If the pregnancy with the dead fetus continues, it may be gradually resorbed or mummified. Mummification occurs when the foetus dies from a deficient supply of blood, when liquor amnii is scanty, and when no air enters the uterus. It is also a finding in fetus papyraceous, which is the intrauterine demise of a fetal twin, where it is compressed between the membranes and the uterine wall.

The most important post-mortem change in an intrauterine death is maceration, which is an autolytic process by which there is self-disintegration of the body by cellular enzymes. This can occur if the death of the fetus happens days to months before the delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a confirmatory test for seminal stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is a screening test used to identify seminal stains.

This test detects the presence of spermine, which is one of the constituents of semen. A drop of stain taken in a glass slide is charged with picric acid. Under microscopic examination, the needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals indicate the presence of semen.

Screening tests:

  • UV scanning
  • Barberio's test
  • Fluorescent test
  • Seminal acid phosphatase

Confirmatory tests:

  • Microscopic examination for motile or non-motile sperms
  • P30 (Prostate-Specific Antigen/PSA)
  • Monoclonal Antibody Mouse Antihuman Semen- 5 (MHS-5)

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text:
A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case?

FAST - Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein. 

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

It is one of the 4 Ps in the management of liver injuries, which include: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug- The defects are plugged with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects of levodopa decreases by the addition of carbidopa?
questions.solution:
The incidence of cardiac arrhythmias is decreased.

Behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares and delusions are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral carboxylase inhibitors. This is because of the higher levels of dopamine formed in CNS.

The combination of levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor like carbidopa inhibits peripheral adverse effects of dopamine. This decreases the adverse effects like anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. ECG strip obtained is shown in the image below. His BP is 120/76 mm Hg. Vagal maneuvers were tried but failed. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG strip is suggestive of the AV nodal reentry (AVNRT) variant of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. 

PSVT spans a variety of tachycardia that differ based on the pathway of impulse conduction. They include AV node reentry, AV reentry via an accessory pathway, and atrial tachycardia. AVNRT is the most commonly seen pattern of PSVT in healthy adults, especially in women. This form of PSVT is due to the re-entry of the electrical impulse from the AV node to the right atrium via either of the 2 pathways (superior fast pathway and inferior slow pathway).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (green arrows) at 150 bpm - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm. 
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 
 
 
Treatment - Since AVNRT depends on the functionality of the AV node, administering adenosine terminates most cases of tachycardia. This drug transiently blocks AV conduction by activating acetylcholine-sensitive K+ current in the atria, SAN, and AV nodes. These changes lead to a short action potential duration, hyperpolarization of the nodal tissues, and slowing of automaticity.
Intravenous verapamil or diltiazem can be used alternatively in patients who cannot tolerate adenosine.

questions.text: Which of the following measures for controlling malaria is the Urban Malaria Scheme mainly based on?
questions.solution:
The Urban Malaria Scheme is mainly based on anti-larval measures for controlling malaria. In Urban Malaria Scheme, urban areas with a population of >50,000 and a slide positivity rate of ≥5% are included. 

The vector in urban areas breeds in man-made containers. Therefore, anti-larval measures such as larvivorous fish and larvicides are used to control breeding as the primary method of vector control.

In rural areas, anti-adult measures, such as Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) is the primary method of vector control.

questions.text: A 30-year-old  P1L1  woman is found to have an asymptomatic invasive disease of the cervix penetrating to a depth of 4 mm and 6 mm wide. She wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Invasive cervical disease measuring 6mm in width and 4mm in depth is stage IA2. The most appropriate management here would be a radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Stage IA2 is defined as carcinoma is strictly confined to the cervix and the measured stromal invasion is >3 mm and not >5 mm in depth and no wider than 7mm.

For patients who desire to preserve their fertility, radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are the treatment of choice. For women who do not desire to preserve fertility, radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are advised.

Other options:

Option A - Chemoradiation is indicated from stage IB onwards.

Option B - Conization is indicated in women who want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Option D - Simple hysterectomy is indicated in women who do not want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A farmer residing in West Bengal brings his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine immunization. The child has been adequately immunized till now and has already received a measles vaccine during a supplementary immunization activity drive a few months back. What will you administer to him now?

choices.text: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A
OPV booster, DPT booster, JE vaccine and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.solution:
Vaccines to be given at 16 months of age are OPV booster, DPT booster, MR, JE, and Vitamin A.

The child should receive routine doses of the measles vaccine according to the schedule irrespective of the measles supplementary immunisation activity (SIA) dose. So, the second dose of the measles vaccine is also given.

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is endemic in rural agricultural areas, often associated with rice cultivation and flood irrigation. Vaccination for JE is given in endemic states only. Two doses of a live attenuated JE vaccine are given under the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP) schedule. Under the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) schedule, two doses of a new vero cell-derived inactivated JE vaccine are given.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with intense pruritus and vaginal discharge. On examination, the discharge is profuse, thin, greenish-yellow, and frothy, with an offensive odor. Moreover, there are multiple small punctate strawberry spots on the vaginal vault and cervix. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely clinical diagnosis is trichomoniasis. It is most common in the childbearing age group. They usually present with pruritus and characteristic green vaginal discharge. 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: The following image shows a type of cell signaling pathway. Which of the following hormones act through this pathway?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is associated with tyrosine kinase receptors. Insulin acts through this signaling pathway.

Hormones that use receptor tyrosine kinase/ JAK-STAT signaling include

  • Growth hormone
  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor

Other options

Option B: Thyroxine acts through nuclear receptors.

Option C: Cortisol (Glucocorticoids) acts through cytoplasmic receptors.

Option D: Glucagon acts through Gs type of G-protein coupled receptor.

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She informed that she has had fibroids since a long time. The radiological investigation showed fibroids looking like womb stones. What is the type of degeneration that has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Womb-stone appearance is seen in the calcareous degeneration of fibroids.

The blood vessels run in the periphery of fibroids. Along the course of these vessels, phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited. This leads to calcareous degeneration.

Since these depositions are arranged in the periphery in a scattered manner, it gives an appearance of womb-stones of a graveyard surrounding the fibroids.

The best examples of calcareous degeneration are those in old patients with long-standing myomas. 

Hyaline, cystic, and fatty degenerations occur in the central areas of fibroids and have no clinical significance. They are caused by the diminished vascularity in large fibroids.

Radiograph showing large calcified myoma:

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Regarding the dietary goals in preventing Coronary Heart Disease, What is the recommendation on cholesterol intake?
questions.solution:
The recommendation on cholesterol intake for the prevention of CHD is to reduce below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day.

Dietary modification in the prevention of CHD:

  • Reduction of the fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day
  • Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: During a knife fight, a 22-year-old male sustained a stab injury to the abdomen. Which is the most common organ injured in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
The liver is the most common organ damaged in a penetrating stab injury of the abdomen.

  • Most common organ injured in blunt trauma of abdomen: Spleen > Liver
  • Most common organ injured in penetrating abdominal stab injury: Liver
  • Most common organ injured in penetrating gun shot injury: Small intestine.
  • In penetrating abdominal trauma due to stab wounds, the most commonly injured organs are as follows : liver > small bowel > diaphragm > colon.
  • In penetrating abdominal trauma due to gunshot wounds, the most commonly injured organs are as follows  : small bowel > colon > liver >abdominal vascular structures.

questions.text: In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia, which of the following are predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Myelocytes will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. All of the stages of development of granulocytes can be noted on the peripheral smear in varying numbers:

  • Myeloblast - large cells with a round or oval nucleus, cytoplasm is dark and has no granules
  • Myelocyte - nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed.
  • Metamyelocyte - nucleus is like a kidney bean-shaped 
  • Band forms - nucleus is in the shape of C or U.
  • Segmented neutrophils- nucleus has 2-5 lobes.

All the cells except the myeloblast have a granular cytoplasm. Due to the varied appearance of the cells, it is called garden party appearance or college girl's appearance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast, and she was advised to undergo a mammogram. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 2. What will be the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The management plan for this patient would be to undergo routine annual screening.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 2 means that it is a benign lesion, and for these patients, annual screening is advised.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive weakness and chronic fatigue. Physical examination reveals a hard nodule of about 1cm in the prostate. His lab reports reveal low Hb and elevated PSA. Peripheral blood smear shows a normocytic normochromic picture. There are some occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop cells and 2 nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myelophthisic anaemia. Prostatic mass with elevated PSA and age suggestive of prostatic carcinoma, which could be the likely cause in this case.

It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate.

Lab findings of myelophthisic anaemia include:

  • Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image
  • Presence of tear-drop cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet as shown below. Severe fissuring and scaling of the skin are present over the soles. This condition is seen in?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human-crusted scabies. It is the most severe form of scabies, seen in immunocompromised or debilitated patients, including those with neurologic disorders, Down syndrome, organ transplants, Hansen’s disease, or AIDS.

Norwegian scabies

Crusted scabies (Norwegian or hyperkeratotic scabies) is seen in individuals who are immunocompromised due to any underlying disease or therapy, patients with HIV infection, and people who use topical steroids and pimecrolimus.

Individuals who are intellectually challenged, suffering from dementia, or with Down's syndrome are frequently associated with Norwegian scabies. A lack of appreciation of pruritus could be a reason for this.

Crusted scabies occurs in people with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing them to multiply. It is called 'Norwegian' because it was first described in lepers of Norway.

Large warty crusts form on the hands and feet. Palms and soles may be irregularly fissured and thickened. Horny debris get accumulates beneath the thickened and discoloured nails. Erythema and scaling occur in the scalp face and seborrheic area. The itching will be absent often.

Scrappings teeming with mites and eggs confirms the diagnosis. 

All patients should be hospitalized and isolated due to the risk of transmission due to physical contact. Treatment includes oral ivermectin, topical scabicide, and keratolytic agents for the crusting.

The images given below show hands with Norwegian scabies.

questions.text: A new factory has been given a license to fortify salt with iodine. What is the minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level?
questions.solution:
The minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level is 30 ppm.

Level of iodization

  • At consumer level: 15 ppm
  • At production level: 30 ppm

Goitrogens are chemical substances that interfere with iodine utilization by the thyroid gland, leading to the development of goiter. The brassica group of vegetables like cabbage and cauliflower contain goitrogens.

The daily requirement of iodine is 150 mcg for adults and 250 mcg in pregnancy.

Disorders due to iodine deficiency:

  • Goiter
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Retarded physical and mental development
  • Intrauterine death (spontaneous abortion and stillbirth)
  • Endemic cretinism

The National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program conducts surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders. The program conducts a resurvey every 5 years to assess the effect of the impact of iodized salt. They also supply iodized salt and conduct laboratory monitoring of iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed on 21st October every year.

questions.text: Activation of which of the following caspases occurs in pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis that occurs due to the activation of caspase 1.

Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis- The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9 whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3, and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented to the emergency department with signs of shock. Upon further investigations, a diagnosis of a ruptured tubo-ovarian mass was made. At what stage of pelvic inflammatory disease is she in?
questions.solution:
The ruptured tubo-ovarian mass belongs to stage IV of pelvic inflammatory diseases. It usually presents with a sudden worsening of the patient's condition.

Tubo ovarian abscess is a complication of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It can be unilateral or bilateral and is characterized by dull or sharp abdominal pain. It is associated with other features like fever and an adnexal mass. On auscultation, a frictional rub can be heard throughout all quadrants of the abdomen which can be suggestive of a ruptured ovarian abscess. 

Treatment involves the administration of parenteral antibiotics till the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours. Following this, oral doxycycline with either metronidazole or clindamycin is given for 14 days. Ruptured abscess is treated surgically.

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Which is the optimum condition for pigment production in Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
The optimum condition for pigment production in Staphylococcus aureus is the aerobic culture at 22°C.

Characteristics of Staphylococcus growth on nutrient agar:

  • Golden yellow pigmentation on nutrient agar is due to β-carotene.
  • On nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic “oil-paint appearance.”
  • Pigment production is enhanced when 1% of glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium.

questions.text: What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
In the given radiograph, the presence of a single hemivertebra at T9 and concavity to the right in the lower thoracic region is suggestive of congenital scoliosis.

Congenital scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine which is always associated with a radiologically demonstrable anomaly of the vertebral bodies, which includes:

  • Hemivertebrae (where only one-half of the vertebra grows) 
  • Block vertebrae (where two vertebral bodies fuse)
  • An unsegmented bar (a bone bar joining two adjacent vertebrae on one side, which hinders growth on that side)

The image below shows a unilateral and unsegmented bar with contralateral hemivertebra: 

In infantile scoliosis (option C), most curves are thoracic with convexity to the left and the anomalies described above are absent. 

Note: The most progressive type of congenital scoliosis is a concave, unilateral unsegmented bar with a convex hemivertebra.
